TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Scoring Protocol For items in the Analogy, Anomaly, and Antinomy scales, 1 point was awarded for each correct answer

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: For the Antithesis scale, 0.5 point was awarded if a response provided was identified as an acceptable answer based on the scoring key (Table 1)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Another 0.5 point was awarded if participant chose the correct answer for the multiple-choice question

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Four total scores were calculated for the four scales as well as one grand total score was calculated summing them up

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Word Selection We followed the three-word-tier model proposed by Beck and McKeown (1985) when selecting the words to include in the MVKR 2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Tier 1 words represent the most basic words that rarely required instructional attention to their meanings in elementary or middle school, such as clock, baby, happy, and walk

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Tier 2 words, in contrast, represent high-frequency words that are widely used across a variety of domains in both oral and written language

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Some typical Tier 2 words include coincidence, absurd, industrious, fortunate, benevolent, and perform

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Words at this level play a significant role in readers’ repertoire and have been the primary focus of vocabulary instruction in formal school ing (Beck et al., 2013)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Finally, Tier 3 words are those that arise within specific domains, but are rarely used or encountered ine very life, such as isotope, lathe, and refinery

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Words included in the MVKR 2 were mostly Tier 2 words and a few

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Older adolescents and adults are presumed to have some exposure to Tier 2 words, which makes them suitable for assessing vocabulary knowledge for these populations of English-speaking students

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Test Revision The initial scales for the MVKR2 each consisted of 16 multiple-choice items, which resulted in a total of 64 items for the entire measure

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The number was more than the desired number of items (n=40) for the final version of the MVKR 2 in case some of the initial items do not have proper item properties (i.e., item discrimination and difficulty) when tested in the pilot stage, thus should be removed from the final pool

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: I tems were initially developed and then revised iteratively based on the feedback from a group of experts (n=8) in relational reasoning and scale development at a large, mid-Atlantic university

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The experts provided critique and feedback on the format of the four scales as well as on the item quality in open discussions

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Although no quantitative metric was used in panel-based decisions, the revision plan following each critique was evaluated, openly discussed, and reac hed consensus among all panel members

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Then, the initial items were submitted to cognitive labs (n=6) and two pilot tests to examine their functionality, and necessary revisions were made accordingly

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: We made revision decisions based on the problems that we identified during the expert panels, cognitive labs, and pilot tests

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: For example, we identified that the initial format of the Antithesis scale was not appropriate because test takers could rely on the meaning of the option words to find the correct answer without identifying the underlying continuum represented by the two given opposite words

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Fulld etails of the expert panels, cognitive labs, and pilot tests can be found in Supplemental Materials

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 17 The recruited participants for the validation phase were 338 undergraduate students from 4 universities

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Participation was voluntary, and participants could withdraw freely from the study at any time.P articipants were offered an opportunity to enter their email addresses into a raffle for one of three $100 Amazon gift cards

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Further, at the discretion of the individual course instructor who assisted with advertising this study, students who completed the study might receive 1%-2% of extra credits for research participation in their registered course

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The current study was reviewed and approved by the Institutional Review Board (ID: 1674423)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Among the recruited participants, 246 (72.8%) identified as female, 69 (20.4%) as male, 8 (2.4%) reported gender non- binary/non- conforming/self-describe or “prefer not to answer,” and 15 students did not report gender

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Their age ranged from 18 to 55 years (M = 21.90, SD = 4.98)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: In terms of race/ethnicity, 41 (12.1%) identified as African American, 35 (10.4%) as Asian/Asian American, 32 (9.5%) as Hispanic, 180 (53.3%) as White, 4 (1.2%) as Other, and 31 (9.2%) identified as biracial or multiracial

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Regarding class standing, 59 (17.5%) were freshmen, 69 (20.4%) were sophomores, 97 (28.7%) were juniors, 61 (18.0%) were seniors, and 52 (15.3%) had missing values

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: On the question of whether English is their first language, 282 (83.4%) reported “yes,” 41 (12.2%) reported “ no,” and 15 (4.4%) cases had missing values

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Measures Measure of Vocabulary Knowledge through Relational Reasoning The final version of the MVKR 2 consisted of 8 sample items and 32 test items arranged in four scales selected from the initial version

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Following the Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing (American Education Research Association et al., 2014), we aimed to gather empirical evidence

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 18 for the validity of the MVKR2 based on its internal structure and relations to other variables (i.e., convergent and concurrent validity)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: SAT Verbal The final version of the SAT Verbal (SATV) measures vocabulary knowledge, which was used to establish convergent validity of the MVKR2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: It consisted of 12 multiple-choice items that were selected from the SAT Verbal – Initial based on the first pilot data

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: SATV was compiled by previously administered and publicly released SAT sentence completion items

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Only the sentence completion items with one target word were included because they measured participants’ knowledge of contextual use for individual words, which aligned with the definition of vocabulary knowledge in the current study

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Items with multiple target words were excluded because they usually comprised complex syntactic st ructures and semantic relations, thus participant s’ performance on those items would involve knowledge or skills other than vocabulary knowledge

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Test of Relational Reasoning Test of Relational Reasoning (TORR), assessing fluid relational reasoning, was used as another measure to establish convergent validity for the MVKR2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: TORR is a 32-item fluid measure that takes a visual-spatial format to assess four distinct forms of relational reasoning ability –analogy, anomaly, antinomy, and antithesis

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Each scale begins with two sample items intended to familiarize participants with the specific directions and procedures of the eight test items in that scale

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: For each item, the writtend irections were presented at the top followed by a figure problem with four response options displayed below

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The sample items were not scored, and participants were provided with the

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: No additional feedback or explanation was presented for any sample or test item beyond the correct answer option

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The reliability and validity of the TORR were established in Alexander et al

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The internal consistency reliability of TORR as measured by Cronbach’s alpha was.84 and.82 at two times

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Moreover, TORR was found to be significantly and moderately correlated with Raven’s Progressive Matrices (Raven, 1941;r =.49,p <.001), confirming its convergent validity

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The low-moderate correlation of TORR and Shapebuilder (Sprenger et al., 2013), a measure of working memory, atr =.31 (p =.02), supported its discriminant validity

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Further, TORR was found to significantly predict college students’ performance on both the verbal and math SAT items (r =.60 for verbal andr =.36 for math; Alexander et al., 2016), which confirmed its predictive validity

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: SAT Math The final version of the SAT Math (SATM) measuring mathematical performance was used to establish concurrent validity for the MVKR2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Previous studies found that math performance was closely related with fluid relational reasoning (Zhao et al., 2021) and vocabulary knowledge (Carlson et al., 2011; Dunston & Tyminski, 2013)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Thus, it is reasonable to speculate that performance on the MVKR 2, which depend on both fluid relational reasoning and vocabulary knowledge, should be predictive of mathematical performance as assessed by SATM

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: SATM consisted of 12 selected- response items that were selected from the SAT Math – Initial based on the first pilot data

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: SATM was compiled by previously administered and publicly released SAT math items

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Participants were instructed to work through the given math problems and choose one answer from the five given options

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 20 Procedures Participants completed all the measures for the validation phase online via Qualtrics in two sessions

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: In the first session, they were asked to complete the consent form, demographic measure, the MVKR2, and the SAT Verbal

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: In the second session, they were asked to complete the TORR and SAT Ma th

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The procedures followed for this validation phase were the same as those described in the section of Pilot Tests in Supplemental Materials

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Results Descriptive Statistics The descriptive statistics, including the means, standard deviations, and data distribution for all the administered measures, are presented in Table 2.T he data could be considered normally distributed for the total and scale scores of all the administered measures, given that all their skewness and kurtosis estimates fell within the- 2 to 2 range (George & Mallery, 2010)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: We followed the argument-based approach to validation (Kane, 2013) when evaluating the validity of the MVKR 2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Specifically, our analyses focused on scoring, generalization, and extrapo lation inferences in Kane ’s framework

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The scoring inference included item analyses (i.e., item difficulty and discrimination) and analyses of the factor structure, which provided backing support for interpreting the scores of MVKR2 as intended

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The generalization inference here referred to the internal consistency reliability that provided warrants for generalizing the interpretations of the MVKR2 scores over conditions of observation

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The extrapolation inference aimed to exam ine the relations between the scores of the MVKR2 and scores based on “ criterion ” assessments, which could also be considered as convergent and concurrent validity assessments

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The difficulty and discrimination for each item in the MVKR2 were examined under the classical test theory (Table 3)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: All items on the MVKR2 except Antinomy i tem 4 (.83) fell within the ideal difficulty range of.30 to.80 (Wainer & Thissen, 2001)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The most difficult item was Antithesis 4 with a difficulty index of.31

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Further, the MVKR2 items revealed a relatively balanced distribution in terms of difficulty level

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Ten items were judged as difficult (.30-.50), 12 as moderately difficult (.50-.70), and 10 as easy items (.70-.83)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: This index represents the correlation between respondents’ performance on a given item and the scale score

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: A high value indicates that respondents’ performance on that item well reflects their overall ability as represented by their performance on the entire scale

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The discrimination values of the 32 MVKR2 items ranged from.26 to.58 with a median of.42

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: In practice, items with values of.10 or above could be classified as acceptable,.10-.30 as fair, and above.30 as good, in discriminating between high- ability and low-ability test takers (University of Washington, 2021)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: All items on the MVKR2 had discrimination values over.10, with 27 items over.30, which means that most MVKR2 items could well differentiate between those respondents with deeper and shallower vocabulary knowledge

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Factor Structure.T he overall factor structure of the MVKR2 was examined by a series of confirmatory item factor analyses

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The overarching goal of the factor analyses was to examine the dimensionality of word relational knowledge assessed by the MVKR2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: In other words, the factor analyses would provide evidence to support whether word relational knowledge, as assessed by the MVKR2, should be better considered as a unidimensional construct or a multidimensional construct.C onsistent with the previous psychometric works on relational

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 22 reasoning (Alexander, Dumas, et al., 2016; Alexander, Singer, et al., 2016; Dumas & Alexander, 2016; Zhao et al., 2021), we tested a unidimensional model (Model A) and a multidimensional model (Model B)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Model A was a one- factor, unidimensional model in which a general latent factor, word relational knowledge, explained the relations among all the 32 items

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: We further tested a higher-order model (Model B) in which we modeled four latent factors each representing word relational knowledge of a specific higher-order relation as well as an overarching higher- order factor to account for any resulting association among them

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: If ModelB was found to fit the data better than Model A, it would provide one piece of evidence supporting the multidimensional hypothesis

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: We further included a bifactor model (Model C) as a source of triangulation to gain validity of the findings

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Bifactor models usually include a general factor explaining the shared variances among all the individual items as in unidimensional models (i.e., word relational knowledge)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: They also include specific grouping factors (i.e., MVKR2 Analogy, MVKR2 Anomaly, MVKR2 Antinomy, MVKR2 Antithesis), which are usually set to be orthogonal to each other as well as to the general factor, to explain the shared variances among subsets of items over and above the ge neral factor

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Bifactor models are commonly used as dimensionality tests in psychometric analys es (Rodriguez et al., 2016 ; Zhao et al., 2022)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: If the shared variance explained by the general factor is found to be large enough, the scale can be considered unidimensional (Hoffmann et al., 2021; Rodriguez et al., 2016), even if the bifactor model or other multidimensional models yield accept able model fit

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The confirmatory item factor analyses were conducted in Mplus 8.0 (Muthén & Muthén, 2017), with each item score declared as binary categorical variable

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: We fit the three models with the weighted least squares mean and variance adjusted estimator (WLSMV), which is a robust

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 23 estimator for modeling categorical or ordered data (Brown, 2006; Proitsi et al., 20 11)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: In selecting the best-fitting model, we considered comparative fit index (CFI) ≥.90, Tucker –Lewis index TLI ≥.90, root-mean-square error of approximation (RMSEA) ≤.08, and standardized root-mean-square residual (SRMR) ≤.10 as acceptable model fit (Hau et al., 2004)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The results suggest that Model A fit the data poorly, yet ModelB andC both had acceptable fit

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Moreover, the explained common variance (ECV) of the general factor in ModelC did not exceed the criterion value (0.7), suggesting that the one general factor could not explain enough shared variance among all the MVKR2 items

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Taken together, these results suggest that word knowledge as measured by MVKR2 should not be considered simply as a unidimensional construct, but better as a multidimensional construct with four dimensions capturing the knowledge of specific word relations and one overarching dimension of word knowledge accounting for the association among these dimensions, which aligns with the higher- order model (Model B)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Details of model specification and comparisons can be found in Supplemental Materials

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: An examination of dimensionality based on the tested bifactor model was also included in Supplemental Materials (i.e., calculation of thee xplained common variance)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Generalization Inference The internal consistency reliability of the four scale factors of the MVKR 2 were represented by the McDonald’s ω (McDonald, 1985, 1999)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The higher-order model (Model B) was selected as the measurement model for calculating omega for the four scale factors

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The omega coefficients for the Analogy, Anomaly, Antinomy, and Antithesis scales were ω=.91,.92,.94, and.93, respectively

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: We also calculated the internal consistent reliability for the entire test based on the bifactor model (Model C)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 24 which can parse out the variability attributable to subfactors and calculates reliability for a general factor that applies to all items, and is thus recommended for bifactor models (Cho, 2022; McNeish, 201 8)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Extrapolation Inference Convergent and concurrent validity of MVKR2 were examined through correlations

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Correlations indicated that MVKR2 had moderate to strong correlations with all the other three measures (.42≤r≤.70, ps <.001; Table 4)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Thus, performance on the MVKR2 converged with performance on assessments of fluid relational reasoning (i.e., TORR) and vocabulary knowledge (i.e., SATV), and also predicted performance on a distal yet important academic domain (i.e., math performance)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Take together, these results provided empirical evidence to the criterion-based validity of the MVKR2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Phase III: Unique Contributions of Fluid Relational Reasoning and Vocabulary Knowledge The second research question guiding this study asked about the unique contributions of fluid relational reasoning ability and vocabulary knowledge to participants’ performance on the MVKR2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: To address this question, we examined those contributions of vocabulary knowledge and fluid relational reasoning ability at the test, scale, and item levels

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Test-Level Examination An SEM analysis using Mplus 8.0 indicated an acceptable fit for the model that examin ed the contributions of fluid relational reasoning ability and vocabulary knowledge to word relational knowledge on the test level (Figure 6 ; 𝜒𝜒2 = 2140.44, df = 2005,p =.018; RMSEA =.01, RMSEA 90%C.I

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Latent word relational knowledge was modeled by the MVKR2 items following the higher-order factor structure (Model B)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 25 items following a higher- order factor structure (Alexander, Dumas, et al., 2016)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The word relational knowledge factor was further regressed on fluid relational reasoning and SAT Verbal total score

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Vocabulary knowledge and fluid relational reasoning uniquely and significantly contributed to word relational knowledge (path coefficients =.61,.36, ps<.001)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: This implies that 37.21% and 12.96% of the variance in word relational knowledge is explained by vocabulary knowledge and fluid relational reasoning ability, respectively

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The test-level exam ination confirmed that performance on the MVKR2 depends on vocabulary knowledge and fluid relational reasoning with vocabulary knowledge emerging as the stronger predictor for college students

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Scale-Level Examination The scale-level examination aimed to assess the unique contributions of latent fluid relational reasoning and latent vocabulary knowledge to each scale of MVKR2

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: A structural equation modeling (SEM) analysis in Mplus 8.0 with maximum likelihood estimation was performed, loading TORR scale scores on the relational reasoning factor only, SAT verbal total score on the vocabulary knowledge factor only, and MVKR2 scale scores on both factors (Figure 7)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Model fit indices (𝜒𝜒2 = 51.65, df = 24,p =.001; RMSEA =.06, RMSEA 90%C.I

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: = [.0 36,.080] ; CFI =.97, TLI =.95, SRMR =.06) indicated an acceptable fit

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: All TORR scales loaded significantly on the relational reasoning factor, as did the SAT Verbal total score on the vocabulary knowledge factor

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: MVKR2 scales showed significant loadings on the vocabulary knowledge factor, with Analogy and Antinomy also loading on the relational reasoning factor

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Variances explained by relational reasoning for the Analogy, Anomaly, Antinomy, Antithesis scales of the MVKR 2 were 1.74%, 0.48%, 6.40%, and 1.66%, whereasv ocabulary knowledge explained 36.70%, 48.70%, 19.98%, and 33.99% of variances

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 26 relational reasoning and vocabulary knowledge factors was moderate (r =.44,p <.001)

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The results suggest that individual differences in vocabulary knowledge were still the driving force in explaining the variability of performance on the MVKR2 compared to fluid relational reasoning, yet relational reasoning did not contribute to the performance on the Anomaly and Antithesis scales MVKR2 to the same extent as the Analogy and Antinomy scales

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Item-Level Examination The item- level examination aimed to discern the contributions of fluid relational reasoning and vocabulary knowledge on MVKR2 item performance

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Using four two-dimensional IRT models, each representing a form of relational reasoning, data were analyzed with the WLSMV estimator in Mplus 8.0

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Items from Analogy, Anomaly, and Antithesis scales were loaded on correlated relational reasoning and vocabulary knowledge factors, while for the Antinomy scale, the correlation between these two factors were fixed at a value of 0.5 due to convergence issues

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Most TORR and all SAT Verbal items loaded exclusively on fluid relational reasoning and vocabulary knowledge factors, respectively

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: The standardized item-factor loadings indicated that vocabulary knowledge predominantly contributed to MVKR2 performance, with all items in Analogy, Anomaly, and Antinomy scales significantly loaded on the vocabulary knowledge factor

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: In contrast, fluid relational reasoning only significantly contributed to the Antithesis scale

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: See details of model specification and factor loading details in Supplemental Materials

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Despite earli er findings at test- and scale-levels supporting the importance of relational reasoning, the item-level examination revealed that relational reasoning played a significant role only in the Antithesis scale, potentially influenced by its distinct configuration in that it is the only scale that explicitly asked participants first to identify the continuum represented by two opposite words presented

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: It is possible that the added construction component to the antithesis items increased the amount of relational reasoning required for this set of items over those in the other scales

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Conclusions and Implications Before revisiting the findings of the current study, there are particular limitations to the present investigation that must be acknowledged

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Limitations Restricted by available resources in recruiting thousands of participants, this study collected a sample of 338 participants

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Although this sample size allowed for valid statistical inferences for most of the analyses reported in this manuscript, the relati vely small sample size could have affected analyses and findings in two ways

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: For one, we were not able to calibrate the items in the MVKR 2 with accurate estimates for item discrimination, difficulty, and guessing parameters under a multidimensional IRT (MIRT) model

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Although confirmatory item factor analyses were conducted, they should be considered as assessing the overall factor structure of the MVKR 2 rather than obtaining accurate item parameter estimations for calibration purpose

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Contributions and Implications In their influential work, Nagy and Scott (2000) emphasized the interrelated nature of vocabulary, highlighting the limitations of existing assessments in capturing the nuances of individuals' knowledge of word relations

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: This study introduces a novel perspective by assessing vocabulary knowledge through relational reasoning, moving beyond isolated or context- dependent evaluations

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: 28 DRLRL, 2012b),t he Measure of Vocabulary Knowledge through Relational Reasoning (MVKR2) explores semantic relations among words within four higher-order relations

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: A key innovation lies in the application of the relational reasoning framework to assess ing nuanced word meanings

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Unlike traditional assessments, MVKR2 evaluates participants' understanding of semantic relations among words within complex networks

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: This unique approach uncovers in- depth knowledge by requiring individuals to compare meanings and analyze semantic relationships, reflecting the integration of their semantic network

TITLE: Investing a Novel Approach to Assessing Vocabulary Knowledge
SENTENCE: Difficulty and discrimination analyses confirmed appropriate item difficulty and discrimination, enhancing the measure's robustness

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Techniques were coded as positive if they were associated with a sig-nificant outcome for comprehension, whereas techniques were coded as negative if students performed significantly worse on comprehension outcomes or if there was a decrement in learning

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

SENTENCE: With few exceptions (Alvarez, 1993; Alvarez & Risko, 1989; Carriedo & Alonso-Tapia, 1995; Kaefer, 2020), participants infre-quently read narrative texts

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Grade Levels Across the 88 investigated techniques, nearly half (48%) included undergradu- ate participants (n = 42)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Although some studies investigated techniques across grade levels (e.g., Gurlitt & Renkl, 2008), fewer studies explored knowledge acti- vation with high school (n = 20), middle school (n = 18), upper elementary (n = 20), and lower elementary (n = 2) students

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: These results illuminate a dearth of research on activation techniques for younger students

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: One potential explanation is that the stress in early grades is on acquiring foundational reading skills

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Despite this paucity of research, elementary teachers are often encouraged to activate their students’ knowledge before reading

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Addressing Misconceptions Nine articles addressed the issue of students’ misconceptions, all within the domain of science (e.g., Alvermann et al., 1985; Biemans et al., 2001)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Misconceptions can influence students’ reading (Kendeou et al., 2014) and are particularly prevalent in science (Treagust, 1988)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Researchers in the included studies addressed misconceptions through augmented activation, refutation texts, or analogical reasoning

SENTENCE: Augmented activation is when students are told that what they are about to read may be different from what they already know (Alvermann & Hynd, 1989), refutation texts state and refute common scientific misconcep-tions (Alvermann & Hague, 1989), and analogical reasoning uses analogies as a tool to address misconceptions (Braasch & Goldman

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: However, miscon-ceptions are different from irrelevant knowledge, which is knowledge extraneous to the text at hand, although not necessarily incorrect (Kaefer, 2020; Mannies et al., 1989).

SENTENCE: 88In contrast to what others have reported (Alvermann & Hague, 1989; Kendeou et al., 2014), Pressley et al

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: (1990) found that activating students’ inaccurate infor- mation may not be detrimental to comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Therefore, students’ inaccurate prior knowledge may shift more easily than established scientific misconceptions

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Further, Hattan and Alexander (2021) examined the use of relational reasoning prompts that asked students how their knowledge may be different from or in conflict with the social studies texts they were reading, which proved helpful to their comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Again, misconceptions were not the focus of that study, but such structured prompts could support students in addressing either inaccurate or incomplete prior knowledge vis-à-vis text content

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Before, During, or After Reading Overall, prior knowledge activation occurred primarily before reading

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In fact, 47 of the 88 techniques solely addressed knowledge activation before reading, while 65 of the techniques included a prereading prompt, even if it was combined with during or after reading activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Knowledge activation was initiated solely during reading in 19 of the techniques, while 28 techniques included during read-ing scaffolds in addition to before or after reading activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: There were 17 instances when postreading activation took place alongside before or during read-ing but only 1 instance when knowledge activation occurred solely after reading

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: From a practical perspective, these results are not surprising, as teachers are often encouraged to activate students’ knowledge, typically topic-specific knowl-edge, prior to reading or engaging with course content (Hattan et al., 2015)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: However, as mentioned, the Construction Integration Model of Text Comprehension (Kintsch, 1998) emphasizes a continuous interaction between the reader and the text, suggesting the importance of also scaffolding students’ knowl-edge activation during or after reading

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: As such, the activation of prior knowledge during and after reading may support knowledge integration and learning from texts (Hattan & Lupo, 2020)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: This illuminates the importance of clearly delineat-ing the process of knowledge activation, which should then map onto the knowl-edge activation techniques that are investigated in the studies

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Individual or Collaborative Activation The vast majority of techniques required participants to activate their prior knowledge individually (n = 71), with fewer techniques supporting pair (n = 3) or group (n = 14) activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Given that many studies took place in lab-like set- tings with undergraduate participants, this pattern is not surprising

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: However, reading is not only an individual pursuit, but also a social practice (Street, 1984)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: As such, more research is needed around how shared knowledge activation, in contrast to individual activation, influences readers’ overall comprehension of text or may either mitigate or exacerbate the inaccurate understandings that indi-viduals hold relative to the topic or domain.

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: To What Extent Are Positive, Negative, Neutral, or Mixed Outcomes Associated With Those Categories

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In order to explore how knowledge activation was operationalized, categories were generated based on shared attributes of the 30 unique techniques included in this review

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: As displayed in Table 3, those techniques fell into eight categories: open-ended prompts, procedural or strategic supports during reading, visual rep-resentation, analogical reasoning, text alteration, augmented activation, extratex-tual activities, and spontaneous activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Although there is no explicit hierarchy to the derived categories, the following sections begin with the most common category: open-ended prompts

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: The second category, procedural and strategic supports, was similar to open-ended prompts in that they often included teacher questioning, but they differed from those prompts in that there were more explicit attempts to reinforce certain reading behaviors

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: The third through fifth categories dealt more expressly with how concepts con-nect to each other (i.e., visual, analogical reasoning, and text alteration)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: For example, visual representations helped students understand how their prior knowledge of concepts and subconcepts related to each other via concept maps; analogical reasoning supported students in considering how their prior knowledge may be similar to the text at hand; and text alteration is when the texts students read were manipulated in some way, sometimes prompting students to consider how a concept they presumably understood (e.g., tire pressure) could help them learn about a new concept (e.g., wind flow patterns)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: The sixth and seventh categories described augmented activation and extratex- tual activities

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: These two categories are presented consecutively since the research regarding the effectiveness of extratextual activities was quite mixed, but the negative effects of extratextual activities could sometimes be mitigated with the use of augmented activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Finally, information on spontaneous activation is presented, which has the least amount of empirical evidence and also requires less explicit prompting

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Specifically, each knowledge activation technique (n = 88) was coded according to whether it improved students’ reading performance or not

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: (See last column in Table S3.) For the 88 documented instances, 51 resulted in positive effects on readers’ learning or comprehension, whereas 15 demonstrated negative outcomes

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Another eight cases reported no significant outcomes, and an addi-tional eight recorded mixed outcomes depending on the outcome measure used

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: The remaining six instances were qualitative or exploratory studies that did not quantitatively assess the influence of activation on learning or comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Effect sizes were reported for 20 of the 88 instances of prior knowledge activa- tion techniques

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In some cases, prior knowledge activation was integrated into a larger intervention (Andreassen & Bråten, 2011)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In those instances, the influence of the entire intervention on student learning was examined since the unique influ-ences of prior knowledge activation could not be determined

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: To investigate the effectiveness of prior knowledge activation techniques on comprehension out-comes, patterns were identified within each of the eight categories in an effort to

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts 91discern whether, when, how, and for whom the techniques facilitate comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Open-Ended Prompts Open-ended prompts, which asked students to respond to questions by sharing everything they knew related to a question, were investigated in 23 of the 54 articles, making it the largest category

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: These prompts typically asked students to consider what they already knew about a particular topic

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: One exception was when students were asked to activate their knowledge of metacognitive strategies (Kostons & van der Werf, 2015)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In most instances, open-ended questions were posed before reading; however, occasionally readers were asked to share what they knew after reading as well (Andreassen & Bråten, 2011)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In this category, participants ranged from lower elementary school through college, and the domains included social studies, science, and reading

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Across the studies, open-ended prompts occurred through individual written knowledge activation (Peeck et al., 1982), as well as via whole class (Dole et al., 1991), small group (Schmidt et al., 1989) or paired discussions (Kiili et al., 2012)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Analyses revealed that the effectiveness of open-ended knowledge activation varied by grade level, as well as the degree to which the prompts were collabora-tive in nature

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: For example, Hattan and Alexander (2021) found that individual, written knowledge mobilization did not support fifth- and sixth-grade students’ text comprehension in comparison to a more structured relational reasoning tech-nique or a control condition

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Yet researchers found that upper elementary and middle school students who responded to open-ended prompts via whole class, group, or paired discussions, experienced positive comprehension outcomes (Andreassen & Bråten, 2011; Bråten et al., 2017, Dole et al., 1991)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Therefore, it is possible that the opportunity to discuss with peers may be particularly impor- tant for knowledge activation with upper elementary and middle school students

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Additionally, Stahl (2008) provided opportunities for lower elementary stu- dents to respond to open-ended prompts both individually and collaboratively via a Know-Want to learn-Learned (KWL) chart

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: However, in this study, KWL did not lead to improved performance on maze, vocabulary recognition, or free recall tasks

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Perhaps due to their more limited experiences and background knowledge, younger students require more structured knowledge activation support to guide them in accessing relevant knowledge

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Of course, additional studies are needed to explore possible reasons for those findings

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In contrast to mixed results for elementary and middle-school students, open- ended prompts appeared to facilitate text comprehension more consistently for high school (Martin et al., 1986) and undergraduate students (Hattan & Alexander, 2018; Pressley et al., 1990)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: However, although studies on high school students included both individual (e.g., Wetzels, Kester, & van Merriënboer, 2011) and collaborative (e.g., Lupo et al., 2019) knowledge activation, all researchers who investigated undergraduate students’ responses to open-ended prompts did so via individual writing and not discussion

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Two studies involving the use of open-ended knowledge activation with high school students had particularly interesting results

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: For one, Guzzetti (1990) reported no significant differences on application problems between high school

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

SENTENCE: However, qualitative analyses of interviews revealed that while students often thought that they did not have any relevant prior topic knowledge about Boyle’s law, they, in fact, had prior experiences that they accurately related to the text topic

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: (2012) examined students’ talk while activat-ing knowledge, reading, and writing a collaborative essay

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Although the study did not include a comparison group, the researchers found five collaborative reading profiles, ranging from coconstructors to silent readers

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: These results suggested that high school students may have varying levels of comfort and different approaches to sharing their knowledge via open-ended discussion

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In another study, Wetzels, Kester, and van Merriënboer (2011) compared written, open-ended mobilization to perspective taking, which asked students to examine a picture of a heart from the perspective of a blood ves-sel

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: They found that open-ended mobilization was more beneficial for high school students presumed to have lower topic knowledge, compared to undergraduate students assumed to have higher topic knowledge

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: The authors explained that mobilization allows students to “freely activate a set of concepts that are only loosely connected and have not yet developed into a coherent knowledge struc-ture,” (p

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Analysis of the outcomes also revealed that activating irrelevant or incompat- ible information prior to or during reading could hinder comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: (1989) found that mobilizing relevant information was helpful for middle school students’ free recall, whereas mobilizing irrelevant information impaired students’ comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Collectively, these results support the idea that there may be a knowledge threshold for open-ended prompts to be useful (O’Reilly et al., 2019)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: That being said, for upper elementary and middle school students, peer discussions may help bridge the gap with collective knowl-edge activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Yet, substantially more research is needed on lower elementary students’ knowledge activation, for whom this type of open-ended prompting, even when paired with discussion, does not yet appear to be useful for compre-hension (Stahl, 2008)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Procedural or Strategic Supports During Text Processing The next category of activation techniques involved targeting specific proce- dures or strategies during reading as a means of using students’ existing knowl-edge to enhance comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Across 12 articles, an array of instructional procedures were used or strategic processes were reinforced

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Some of the instruc-tional procedures included supports a teacher would provide, such as teacher prompting or periodic questioning (e.g., Carr & Thompson, 1996; Hattan & Alexander, 2020) and providing written prompts (Hattan, 2020)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Other techniques in this category involved procedures that a student is expected to carry out, such

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts 93as the use of a metacognitive support device, which is a computer-supported prompt to think more deeply about their learning

SENTENCE: For example, the computer might prompt students to think about what they want to learn from a text (Bannert et al., 2009)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Another technique that students would engage in is completion of a conditional knowledge questionnaire in which students would reflect on their goals for reading, strategies they would use to help them achieve those goals, and strategies they would avoid that might hinder their text understanding (Bouffard-Bouchard, 1994)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

SENTENCE: When compared to a control group not receiving any treatment, these proce- dural and strategic supports tended to positively affect comprehension and learn-ing (Azevedo et al., 2007; Bannert et al., 2009; Elbro & Buch-Iversen, 2013; Spires & Donley, 1998)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Wetzels, Kester, and van Merriënboer (2011) found benefits for both perspective taking and mobilization; while Hattan and Alexander (2021) only found benefits for relational reasoning

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Similarly, Carr and Thompson (1996) found that both teacher prompting and spontaneous activation had positive results on readers’ text comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Visual Representation Visual representations required students to create a graphic display of their knowledge related to the text, and also provided opportunities for them to con-sider the relations between various concepts and subconcepts

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Four articles in the current review examined students’ use of visual representations via concept maps

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: All four articles focused on high school or undergraduate students and primarily led to positive comprehension results for these older readers

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: When comparing visual representations to control groups or other forms of knowledge activation (Alvarez, 1993; Hattan & Alexander, 2018), concept maps led to significantly better text comprehension

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: However, results were more nuanced when consider- ing the timing (e.g., before or after reading), the structure of visuals, and partici-pants’ relevant knowledge

SENTENCE: (2015) compared the development of concept maps before reading to after reading

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: To examine the structure of visual representations, Gurlitt and Renkl (2008) asked high school and undergraduate students to either create and label lines in a con-cept map, or label lines on an already created map

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: These researchers reported that high school students (who they assumed had less content knowledge) benefited from labeling provided lines

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: By comparison, undergraduate students (who the researchers assumed had more knowledge) benefited from creating and labeling lines

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In addition to considering timing and structure, the measures used to assess students’ comprehension could lead to different effects depending on the outcome measure

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: For example, Gurlitt and Renkl (2010) assessed students’ comprehen-sion with think-aloud protocols coded for elaboration, organization, and model

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Overall, these studies support the use of visual representations for activating students’ prior knowledge during text processing

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: However, more research is needed to determine at what point during the reading process visual representa-tions are most beneficial

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Extratextual Activities The techniques included in this specific activation category involved the use of some extratextual activity or experience meant to instantiate or trigger students’ knowledge for the upcoming reading

SENTENCE: For example, Guzzetti (1990) included teacher demonstrations where the instructor placed a balloon inside a glass jar, students watched as air pressure decreased and the balloon volume increased, and then students discussed their reactions to the experiment to activate their knowl-edge

SENTENCE: Additional activities employed prereading illustrations (Alvermann & Hague, 1989), incorporated prereading statements via anticipation guides (Adams, 1982), included pretests that were explicitly meant to activate students’ prior knowledge (Kaefer, 2020), or used a cloze task procedure (Salminen et al., 2010)

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: In all but one of eight studies in this category (Kaefer, 2020), the participants were high school students or undergraduates

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: Spontaneous Activation The category of spontaneous activation included three studies in which stu- dents were not expressly directed to reflect on their existing knowledge prior to reading

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: The researchers found that there was no relation between the fre-quency at which students referred to their prior knowledge and experiences and their comprehension performance

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
SENTENCE: These researchers found that unsolicited or spontaneous knowledge activation occurred in about one-third of students’ knowledge activation utterances

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation

SENTENCE: 98that students in the experimenter activation condition had higher comprehension scores than students in the spontaneous activation condition, although those dif-ferences were not significant

TITLE: Leveraging What Students Know to Make Sense of Texts- What the Research Says About Prior Knowledge Activation
