TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education The second phase of explicit instruction involves introducing and then practicing the four essential componential processes critical to any form of relational reasoning (Sternberg, 1977): encoding, inferring, mapping, and applying

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Alexander and colleagues have conducted explicit training in analogical reasoning with very young children through young adults using the componential processes as the framework (White and Alexander, 1986; Alexander et al., 1987a,b; Pate et al., 1989)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Simply deﬁned, encoding entails examining elements of a problem or problem space to ensure understanding of any givens, whereas inferring requires ﬁnding connections between individual elements based on whatever meaning was derived from encoding

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: These two processes thus result in a meaningful association essential for any pattern, even a simple linear sequence

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: However, unlike simple linear patterns, relational reasoning forms involve “relations among relations.” Mapping is the componential process that is required to link the initial pattern just inferred to another set of associated elements that represent a related pattern

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: The ﬁnal componential process, applying, involves completing the problem and recognizing the underlying structure, which could then be iterated

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: To illustrate these componential processes, we let students see how they function in a simple analogy problem like “ocean: bay: continent: _ X_.” Students begin by encoding the term ocean and identifying its salient attributes (largest body of water) and then encoding the term bay (inlet of water connected to a larger body of water like an ocean and surrounded by land on three sides)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Next students must infer a relation between ocean and bay (both are bodies of water, but bays are smaller and open to oceans on one side and surrounded by land on the remaining sides), To complete the mapping, students must form a meaningful association between ocean and continent (both are the largest geographical bodies of water and land, respectively)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Finally, applying means that students must identify the critical attributes of the missing element that would parallel the relation of ocean to bay

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Speciﬁcally, they need to recognize that they are looking for a small body of land, connected to a continent on one side and water on the remaining three sides (answer: peninsula)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: While the componential processes of encoding, inferring, mapping, and applying were conceptualized with only analogical reasoning in mind (Sternberg, 1977), Grossnickle et al

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: (2016) found that those same processes were core to anomalous, antinomous, and antithetical reasoning, as well

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Moreover, these researchers found that lower performing students exhibited diﬃculties inferring and mapping on problems representing all relational reasoning forms

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Thus, once students had practiced using the componential processes on verbal analogy problems, they were introduced to verbal problems tapping anomalous, antinomous, and antithetical reasoning

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: As with the analogy problems, they were directed to encode, infer, map, and apply while solving these problems and received feedback on their performance

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: When this training and practice phase concluded, our goal was to demonstrate the importance of relational reasoning to other key facets of academic learning and performance beginning with transfer

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Phase 3: Expansion and Transfer Transfer, “the process of using knowledge or skills acquired in one context in a new or varied context” (Alexander and Murphy, 1999,p

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: 561), has the well-earned reputation of being one of the most challenging cognitive abilities for students to master (Gick and Holyoak, 1980; Detterman and Sternberg, 1993)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Indeed, the literature is replete with evidence that students are typically poor at transferring knowledge and skills from one formal learning environment to another or to situations in the world outside the classroom (Perkins and Salomon, 2012)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: This indictment notwithstanding, transfer remains a foundational ability for all students, especially tertiary students, to develop and hone if they are to be successful both in their university studies and their chosen professions

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Many factors or conditions have been proposed as barriers of transfer such as the contention that the initial learning was not substantive enough to foster transfer (Dinsmore et al., 2013)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: It could also be that the new context appears quite dissimilar to the context in which the knowledge and skills were acquired

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Learners’ individual characteristics can also foster or frustrate transfer including their perceptiveness, motivations, or metacognitive and strategic abilities (Corkill and Fager, 1995; Billing, 2007; Dinsmore et al., 2013)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Because of the importance of transfer for learning in higher education and for future career success, this area is stressed in Frontiers in Education | www.frontiersin.org 10 May 2022 | Volume 7 | Article 883370

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: We concur with Billing (2007) that transfer is more likely to occur when principles of reasoning are taught in conjunction with academic content

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Thus, when we introduce this topic to students, we stress that learning to transfer will “bootstrap” the knowledge and skills they are working hard to acquire

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: A ﬁrst step in forming this habit of mind is for them to become perceptive and alert to transfer opportunities—a process that can be aided by their use of relational reasoning

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: We share evidence with them that shows that analogical reasoning ability can be a key to transfer (Reeves and Weisberg, 1994; Richland and McDonough, 2010)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: As Alexander and Murphy (1999) argued, transfer and analogical reasoning are related processes

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Unless students can perceive similarities between a speciﬁc task they learned with another task encountered in a diﬀerent context, they will not be primed to engage in transfer

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Further, the more these students can look beyond the surface features of those tasks and contexts and ﬁnd underlying similarities, the better they can make use of what they already know and can do, which is where their relational reasoning, and especially analogical reasoning can be most helpful (Richland and McDonough, 2010)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: We also alert students to be aware of the dissimilarities between the initial tasks and contexts and these transfer opportunities, so they can iterate or modify their problem-solving processes appropriately

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: When this instruction on transfer coupled with relational reasoning has been completed, students in LHL are given the task of documenting as many instances of transfer as they can within a 24-h period

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: The cases of transfer the students record are then discussed in class for added reinforcement

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Critical Reading is another basic skill for students in tertiary education, as they are required to read about what they are studying

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: For students majoring in certain ﬁelds, such as history, philosophy, psychology, and sociology, the reading required can be quite extensive

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: In LHL, for instance, students are reading, summarizing, and comparing articles and chapters routinely

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: They also are required to carry out a multiple-source use (MSU) project for which they conduct an online search on a controversial topic (e.g., The eﬀects of overuse of social media on students’ academic, social, physical, and emotional well-being)

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: The students then select and summarize appropriate sources to use as the basis for an argumentative essay

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: The students’ prior training in relational reasoning becomes relevant to these tasks in several ways

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: For one, we recognized early in the rollout of this course that many of these tertiary students did not have eﬀective strategies for dealing with course readings in an integrative manner

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Thus, when they were tasked with writing a comparison of two readings that oﬀered diﬀerent perspectives on an issue (e.g., expertise), many had no clue how to begin

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Drawing on their relational reasoning training, we suggested that they could chart key similarities and dissimilarities between the readings and then use that relational analysis to organize their written comparisons

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: This deep analysis technique was also advantageous when the students had to integrate information across multiple documents

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Again, by thinking relationally about the documents in terms of core similarities and dissimilarities, the students were betterprepared to integrate the positions, arguments, and evidence presented in their selected sources

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: The resulting analysis could help them formulate their own position on the controversial issue and provide them with evidence to support their position when composing their argumentative essay

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: As with their writing, we were somewhat surprised to ﬁnd that a good number of the tertiary students enrolled in LHL were stymied in their ability to carry out quality discussion

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Frequently what we witnessed were students voicing points that were unconnected to what others had already been said or they did not make it clear whether their statement was meant to support or counter what others had previously expressed

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: In eﬀect, what should have been a discussion became a string of separate statements

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Thus, what we did to improve the quality of class discussions was to share the research illustrating how professionals like medical doctors diagnosing their patients or engineering students working collaboratively on a project design would use relational reasoning in their discourse to work toward a shared outcome

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: We also had students read an excellent piece by Murphy et al

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: (2017) that describes how instances of relational reasoning in students’ discourse served to reinforce, conditionalize, or counter others’ comments

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Tertiary students in LHL then tried their hands at carrying on a discussion based on their MSU research, and the ideas expressed in their argumentative essays

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: We saw a marked improvement in discussion quality following this brief intervention with many more uptakes

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: deﬁne uptakes as direct acknowledgments of what others have contributed and an explicit indication of how one’s response is related

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: In this ﬁnal section of the article, we have attempted to show how theory and research in relational reasoning can easily and eﬀectively be embedded in instruction within a university classroom

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Of course, we do not know if those students who were part of LHL carried the lessons from this unique course into the rest of their tertiary education or into their continued professional development

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: FINAL THOUGHTS AND FUTURE DIRECTIONS An overarching goal we set for this treatise on relational reasoning was to establish its value as a higher-order cognitive ability for tertiary students’ current learning and performance as well as their future success in their chosen professions

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: To support that claim, we not only shared what is known about the nature, forms, and development of relational reasoning, but also its contributions to a range of human activities and academic domains

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: Finally, we looked at how relational reasoning was woven through the content of one university course—from its assessment and training to its expansion into other topics of importance such as transfer, critical reading, and writing abilities

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: There is no question that higher education has a mission of equipping students with the knowledge and skills they will need to function in their lives, including in their chosen professions

TITLE: Relational Reasoning in Tertiary Education- What Is Its Value and How Can It Be Assessed and Trained
SENTENCE: It is also presumed that tertiary education will contribute to Frontiers in Education | www.frontiersin.org 11 May 2022 | Volume 7 | Article 883370

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: TRAINING RELATIONAL REASONING 2 INTRODUCTION TO THIS TRAINING MANUAL What follows is a manual for instructing secondary or college students in four forms of relational reasoning (RR): analogical, anomalous, antinomous, and antithetical reasoning

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: The training is presented in 6 sessions that includes a pre-assessment (Session I), followed by an overview of RR (Session II), and then multiple sessions devoted to each of the four RR forms (Sessions III–V), ending with a post-assessment of individuals’ RR abilities (Session VI)

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: The manual also contains sample slides that overview the content for each session and specific activities meant to reinforce individuals’ understanding of RR and its specific forms, and to apply that understanding in various ways

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: SESSION I: PRE-ASSESSMENT OF RELATIONAL REASONING Students will be given 50 minutes to complete the Test of Relational Reasoning (TORR) online via Qualtrics©

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Once they submit their responses, they will automatically receive their total score and the corresponding Relational Reasoning Quotient (RRQ; see Appendix A), which converts raw scores into standard scores with a mean of 100 and a standard de viation of 15

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: They will also receive their scores for each scale of the TORR that corresponds to one of the four forms

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: This pre-assessment can either be completed in person or online such that the learner can progress at their own pace

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: For this training, the TORR will be completed outside of class so that there are no time constraints

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Students will be informed that the test needs to be completed in one sitting; there is no stopping and restarting of the test once it is begun.

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: TRAINING RELATIONAL REASONING 3 SESSION II: TORR DEBRIEFING AND OVERVIEW OF RELATIONAL REASONING This session begins with an introduction to relational reasoning as a complex cognitive ability that is essential for learning and performance; core to general and domain-specific problem solving; and a key to knowledge transfer (see Session II slides)

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Following this brief explanation of RR, the TORR is overviewed, starting with the rationale for its creation

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: The TORR is contrast to more traditional measures of cognitive ability (intelligence tests) along a number of dimensions, especially noting that the TORR is a fluid versus crystallized measure and the forms are malleable and trainable

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Then, the descriptive data from the class and discuss what those data indicate about the group’s RR abilities is presented, with emphasis on the importance of the RRQ, which allows for a normative comparison

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Students also reflect on their individual performance relative to the class scores and the normative data

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: To overview the TORR, each of the four forms will be briefly introduced: analogy, anomaly, antinomy, and antithesis (see the relevant slides for each)

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Each form is defined and illustrated with a sample item from the TORR, a sample item from the Verbal Test of Relational Reasoning (vTORR), a pictorial or graphic example

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: At the session's end, the class will be informed that they will be receiving explicit training in each of the four forms over the next class sessions to promote their RR abilities.

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: TRAINING RELATIONAL REASONING 4 SESSION III: TRAINING IN ANALOGICAL AND ANOMALOUS REASONING Analogies Ask students to recall the definition of analogy from Session II

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Then begin Session III by having students complete the Analogy Anchor Activity with the initial problem, HERD : COW:: FLOCK : ________ (Activity 1)

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Use those responses to introduce the four key processes to solving analogies and all other forms: encode, infer, map, and apply

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Encode: Is the process whereby each component of a problem is richly characterized

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: For example, “herd” is a specific name for a group of animals such as sheep, cows, or goats, and “cow” is a single, female, domesticated, four-legged, milk-producing bovine that provides us with meat, cheese, milk, and hides

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Infer: Is the process of generating a relation between the first two terms, herd and cow

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Map: The mapping process requires forming a connection between the two parts of the analogy

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Apply: For the final step, the analogy is completed by finding a term that has the same association with flock that cow has to herd AND importantly that is as attributional ly similar to cow as possible

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: So, to complete the analogy, the response must be a member of a flock that is a single, female, domesticated, four-legged, milk-producing animal that provides us with meat, cheese, milk, and hides

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: To reinforce this understanding, students should correct several of their answers on the Analogy Anchor Activity and explain their reasons for the corrections.

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: TRAINING RELATIONAL REASONING 5 Anomaly As with analogy, ask students to recall the meaning of an anomaly

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Proceed by overviewing how the processes of encoding, inferring, mapping, and applying pertain to anomalies

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Encoding involves richly describing the set of objects that are included in a given set and inferring means determining how each element in the set corresponds to other elements in the set

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Mapping requires the individual to identify specific attributes that differentiate elements in the set (e.g., size, color, category)

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Finally, wh en applying, the respondent needs to select the object within the set that is aberrant on the most attributes

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: For the fish slide from Session 2, only one large fish was red and swimming in the other direction

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: To reinforce the learning, have students complete the short anomaly activity (see Activity 2).

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: TRAINING RELATIONAL REASONING 6 SESSION IV: TRAINING IN ANTITHETICAL AND ANTINOMOUS REASONING As an anchor activity for Session IV, have students complete the Anchor Activity, What Comes to Mind

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Once students have completed the activity, explain that such an exercise demonstrates that humans often think in terms of two conflicting or contrasting ideas

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: The two forms of relational reasoning that the studentsw ill learn about in this session represent such conflicting or contrasting ideas, objects, or events; that is, antithetical reasoning and antinomous reasoning

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: However, these two forms of RR differ from one another in a VERY critical way that often gets ove rlooked

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: As graphically shown in Figure 1, an antinomy represents a binary relation, where the ideas, objects, or events can only belong to one category or the other—with nothing between them

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: For example, in medicine, doctors can certify that someone is alive or dead

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Figure 1 A Graphic Representation of Antinomy and Antithesis In contrast, an antithesis represents a continuum marked by two polarities or opposites

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Unlike antinomies, we can identify many other ideas, objects, or events that fall between two endpoints

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: TRAINING RELATIONAL REASONING 7 Enormous Microscopic Now, see how many words you can position between those two extremes in size

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: In order to test students’ grasp of the difference between antinomy and antithesis, have them go back to Activity 3, What Comes to Mind?

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Then, allow them time to work in groups to decide whether the answers they produced were examples of antinomous or antithetical reasoning

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Students should provide justification for their determinations of antimony or antithesis using the process of encode, infer, map, and apply

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: SESSION V: CULMINATING ACTIVITIES Constructing Novel Relational Items For the last training session in relational reasoning, the student will be given the opportunity to create their own items that represent relational reasoning

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: This can provide you with another form of assessment along with the TORR where the students assess their understanding of each of the relational forms

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Explain to the students that they should create their own item that they believe assesses for each analogy, anomaly, antinomy, and antithesis

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Let the students know that the examples they create can be spatial with shapes or diagrams, like the ones they we re exposed to in the TORR; pictorial using pictures or much more detailed photos, like the ones they were exposed to during the anomaly and analogy training session; or they can be verbal items, where the learner may write out sentence or mix words together in a list, like the examples they were exposed to during the antinomy and antithesis training.

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: TRAINING RELATIONAL REASONING 8 After the students have been given time to create their own example items for each relational form individually, tell them they will now pair up with a peer to share their items

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Demonstrate for the students how they are to explain the item they created,w hat form of relational reasoning they are attempting to assess for, and the instructions for how their peer should choose what they believe is the right answer to the item question

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Then, provide the students time to share their items with their peers and work through each novel example

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Bring the students back together for a large group discussion and have them share what their experience was like creating a novel relational reasoning item and attempting to explain it to their peers

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Make sure that as students share their experiences, you continue to refer students back to salient points from prior training sessions

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: In doing so, students will be continuously coached while they are considering specific challenges related to the relational reasoning forms SESSION VI: POST-ASSESSMENT OF RELATIONAL REASONING Students will complete a post-assessment of relational reasoning

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: The post-assessment is the same version of the TORR that the students took in the pre-assessment during Session I

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: They will be given 50 minutes to complete the TORR online via Qualtrics©.O nce they submit their responses, they will automatically receive their total score and the corresponding RRQ (see Appendix A), as well as their score for each scale of the TORR that corresponds to one of the four forms

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: Students are to record those scores in their journals for their comparison to the pre-assessment

TITLE: RR INSTRUCTION MANUAL
SENTENCE: This post-assessment can either be completed in person or online such that the learner can progress at their own pace.

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Consilience Within Curiosity and Interest Theory and Research Before I map out what I regard as curiosity and interest ’s common ground, there are several caveats to forward

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: First, I am under no illusion that all who identify as curiosity or interest theorists or researchers will find the ensuing points of consilience to their liking

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Second, it is reasonable to assume that these contributing authors ascribe differential importance to the individual claims I have staked out in this commentary

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: My intention was to merely mark these shared conceptions, components, procedures, antecedents, and consequences and not to chart the relative space they occupy within their respective domains

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Finally, I am uncertain if or how this mapping of the common ground shared by curiosity and interest theory and research will ultimately prove useful to future forays into these realms

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: With those caveats in mind, I regard the following as the “unity of knowledge ”unearthed within this special issue

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: The Terms Curiosity and Interest Are Often Ill-Defined and Poorly Demarcated, Especially Within Common Vernacular A point of unity for all contributors to this special issue is that the terms curiosity andinterest are often poorly defined within the professional literature and certainly in everyday discourse

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Sometimes these terms are used interchangeably, while at other times they are cast as overlapping or entirely distinct notions

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: For instance, there are researchers like Silvia (2017) who use the terms curiosity and interest interchangeably, because they contend that the psychobiological data do not support any clear distinction

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: (this issue) regard curiosity and interest as naïve or “folk”conceptions that lack scientific specificity

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Thus, they see efforts to establish more defined boundaries for curiosity and interest as unnecessary and futile

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: In contrast, Hidi and Renninger (this issue) maintain that curiosity and interest have different affective markers, operate on distinct time scales, and have varied “triggers

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: ”For these reasons, they and others (e.g., Ainley this issue ; Peterson and Cohen this issue) proclaim the need for definitions of curiosity and interest that reflect their key concep- tual and procedural distinctions

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Curiosity and Interest Are Both Complex and Multifaceted Constructs Although some of the terrain comprising the common ground for curiosity and interest theory and research remains somewhat unsettled, one area is firmly set

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Specifically, whether the authors in this special issue, and the broader literature, regard curiosity and interest as similar, overlapping, or distinct, they almost invariably portray these constructs as complex, intricate, and multifaceted

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: It is quite likely that these attributes add to the conceptual ambiguity surrounding curiosity and interest

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: This portrayal of complexity for curiosity and interest is not limited to their definitions, but is spoken about in relation to the experiencing of curiosity and interest (Shin and Kim this issue), their “triggers ”or catalysts (Hidi and Renninger this issue), and the profiles of those who manifest either (Ainley this issue)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: The dimensions of human psychology and neurophysiology implicated in displays of curiosity and interest are cognitive, social, affective, and physiological (Peterson and Cohen this issue), cultural, behavioral, and emotional (Shin and Kim this issue), as well as sensory, perceptual, and epistemic (Ainley this issue)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Just contemplating the potential interactions among this myriad of dimensions is strong evidence that curiosity and interest are, indeed, highly complex notions.Educational Psychology Review (2019) 31:897 –904 898

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Further, the multidimensional nature of these constructs is quite apparent in the many iterations populating this special issue, especially pertaining to curiosity

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: For example, there is mention of intellectual curiosity or what Dewey characterizes as children ’s natural desire to make sense of the world they inhabit (Ainley this issue)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Contributing authors (Peterson and Cohen this issue ; Shin and Kim this issue) also reference Litman ’s(2005)not i on sof I-type and D-type curiosity, where the “I”or interest form is aligned with positive emotions (e.g., joy, excitement, or pleasure), whereas the “D”or deprivation form connotes more negative feelings (e.g., tension, anxiety, or frustration)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Additionally, Hidi and Renninger (this issue) differen- tiate between perceptual curiosity and epistemic curiosity

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: With perceptual curiosity, the pursuit is for sensory information —how something feels, smells, or tastes

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Epistemic curiosity, on the other hand, represents the search for relevant information to address a lack of knowledge or understanding

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: There Are More Transient and More Stable Forms of Curiosity and Interest Presumed To Contribute Differentially to Academic Achievement and Human Development There are forms of curiosity and interest that operate on distinctly different time scales

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: For instance, both state curiosity andsituational interest are distinguished by their typically short- lived, fleeting response to real or perceived conditions within the immediate context, what Ainley (this issue) called in-the-moment experiences

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: On the other hand, individual interest is marked by a more enduring interplay between learner characteristics and external conditions that engender more intentional processing and more selective attention

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: ’s(this issue) argument that theory and research in curiosity and interest operate without a priori conceptions, I witnessed a remarkable level of consistency in contributing authors ’characterizations of transient or fleeting displays of curiosity and interest

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: For instance, there was the shared perception that the “triggers ”or“attractors ”for these more state-like manifestations arise from the immediate external context (Shin and Kim this issue)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: It is with regard to the nature of those triggers or attractors and their emotional valences where divergences between curiosity and interest are largely presumed to occur (Hidi and Renninger this issue)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: There was similar consistency in the conception of the more enduring, deep-seated form of interest, individual interest, which is grounded in the writings of Dewey (1913) and reiterated by contemporary interest researchers (Renninger and Hidi 2011; Schiefele 1991 ;W ade 2001)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: In contrast to the more short-lived displays, individual interest is internally powered and, thus, more cross-contextual and cross-situ ational, by nature

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Varied perspectives were noted in contributing authors ’characterizations of the more stable form of curiosity

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: For some of these authors, the predictable display of curiosity (i.e., trait curiosity) is attribut- able to individuals ’inquisitive or probing nature (Hidi and Renninger this issue)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: The target or context for those occurrences is treated as non-specified or generic

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Alternatively, Peterson and Cohen (this issue) proffer a domain-specific view of curiosity

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: This more predictable and reoccurring form of curiosity is predicated on learners ’knowledge and involvement in a particular domain or associated topics, which can drive the formulation of thought-provoking or “curiosity questions ”(i.e., Renninger 2010)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: These curiosity questions can serve as the basis for an active and pleasurable pursuit of information (Alexander and Grossnickle 2016)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Thus, this form of domain-specific curiosity, as with trait curiosity, is sourced within the individual, but it is attached to learners ’academic competences and identity and not to a general personality trait.Educational Psychology Review (2019) 31:897 –904 899

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Curiosity and Interest Share Certain Underlying Components and Processes Even while acknowledging construct distinc tions, the contributing authors to this special issue were in agreement that particular components and processes are common to curiosity and interest

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Among tho se shared components are learners ’knowledge base, their goals, beliefs about self and about knowledge and knowing, and their cognitive and regulatory strategies (Ainley this issue)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: (this issue), who questioned the need for any differentiation between curiosity and interest, incorporated common components in their re ward-learning framework

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Further, both Hidi and Renninger ’s(this issue) four-phase model of interest development and Peter- son and Cohen ’s(this issue) depiction of domain-specific curiosity identify learners ’ knowledge as key to experiences of curios ity or interest

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Epistemic competence, cognition, and beliefs are also portrayed as components of both curiosity and interest that entail the identification of relevant and valid information (Hidi and Renninger this issue ; Peterson and Cohen this issue)

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
SENTENCE: Moreover, learners who have a richer strategic repertoire can employ efficient and effective procedures to seek relevant information when their curiosity is aroused or their inte rest piqued

TITLE: Seeking Common Ground- Surveying the Theoretical and Empirical Landscapes for Curiosity and Interest
