SENTENCE: Therefore, let me throw down the gauntlet to this scholarly assemblage to commit to the systematic, multidis- ciplinary, and multidimensional study of the formal educational experience and the cognitive and socioemotional changes that this experience should ideallyevoke—what I have labeled academic development (Alexander, 2000, 2006; Al- exander, Schallert, & Reynolds, 2009; Alexander, Sperl, Buehl, Fives, & Chiu,2004)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: I first coined the term academic development in my theoretical and empirical writings precisely because no more suitable label for the multifaceted nature of hu-man growth and development could be found (e.g., Alexander, 2000)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Although Iuse the word academic, I wish to assuage any fears that I am dealing with school- ing in narrow cognitive terms

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Rather, the descriptor academic signals the conflu- ence of cognitive, social, emotional, motivational, and cultural factors that con-tribute to optimal student development within the context of formal education

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Specifically, as a way to explicate and justify this new concept of academic de- velopment, my intentions are threefold

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: First, I want to expose several significant myths that presently plague the educational experience and that act as barriers tothe worthwhile goals of this special issue

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Those myths include the mistaken beliefthat achievement, as defined by high-stakes testing, equates to learning, when, infact, such an excessive focus can be detrimental to lifelong, meaningful learning.The needs of students are better served when more time and attention is devoted toconcepts and processes held as central to academic domains, what has been termedprincipled knowledge (Alexander, Murphy, & Woods, 1997; Gelman & Greeno, 1989)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: There are also the myths that mentioning (i.e., “covering the content”)equates to teaching and that the purpose of education is clear

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Second, I hope to convince readers that there is much to be gained when educa- tion is viewed as a developmental process rather than a year-by-year, course- by-course treatment of instructional content

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: This developmental orientation couldhelp to amplify the degree to which a learner’s academic development is muchmore than a coldly cognitive act of accumulating factual tidbits

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: the continual interplay of cognitive and motivational/emotional forces operating within a dynamic sociocultural context

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Third, one of the advantages that comes with viewing formal education as a de- velopmental process is that this orientation could potentially lessen the emphasis on immediate or short-term educational gains and promote contemplation of themore enduring and long-term effects of instructional or curricular decisions

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: I donot wish to suggest that there are no merits to the examination of more short-termoutcomes; there are

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: However, these more “immediate” gains must be consideredin relation to what they suggest about long-term growth and development

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For ex- ample, do we want to risk stifling students’ interest in reading by immersing them in a “drill-and-practice” phonics curriculum devoid of stimulating literature, orrisk turning “struggling readers” into “struggling thinkers” by failing to teach themto think critically and intensively about what they read or hear

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: I would think not.To support this contention, I will share my specific approach to the study of learn- ers’ academic development and the theoretical and methodological insights and challenges that this research program has revealed

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: That theoretical and empiricalprogram centers on the model of domain learning (MDL; Alexander, 1997), whichis an attempt to examine the paths of knowledge, strategic processing, and interestas they interact and intertwine across the lifespan as learners journey toward com-petence or even expertise in academic domains

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Before I delve into educational myths that interfere with the pursuit of aca- demic development, I want to share briefly my personal journey to the realizationthat the very construct of academic development needed to be introduced into theeducational vernacular

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Specifically, over the past 25 years, I have been aggres-sively engaged in the theoretical and empirical study of human learning

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: That pur-suit was a natural outgrowth of my years as a private and public school teacher

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Aswith many in my profession, I chose to become a teacher for altruistic reasons—tohelp students realize their potential through formal education

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Although I consid- ered myself very effective in this honorable profession, I knew that I had much to learn if those altruistic goals were ever to be realized to the level I envisioned

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Thus, I enrolled in a doctoral program in which I found myself enamored with educational research and the potential it held for illuminating the path toward im- proved learning for all who crossed the threshold into the realm of formal educa- tion

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Indeed, I learned much about what was required for students like those I had taught to progress not only in their academics but also in their everyday lives.One of the most important lessons that I learned, however, was that complexproblems like academic development require multidisciplinary problem solving.Even the most gifted teachers or the most forward-thinking educational psychol- ogists cannot hope to bring students to the pinnacle of their academic potential

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: This is the theme of this issue and of this notion of aca- demic development.636 ALEXANDER

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: EDUCATIONAL MYTHS How does one explain how or why certain activities, ideas, or beliefs initially take root within the individual mind or the public conscience, becoming commonplace,routine, or pervasive in character, whereas other comparable activities, ideas, orbeliefs lie fallow or languish

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Ideally, one would hope that a deciding factor be- tween those notions that are ultimately embraced and those that are discredited or discarded would be the credibility or strength of supporting evidence

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Sadly, evena cursory examination of wildly popular fads (e.g., text-messaging while driving,bungee jumping) or shared social practices (e.g., overeating on holidays, living oncredit) offers sufficient refutation of this ideal state

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It is not only the general popu- lace that finds questionable ideas or practices attractive or irresistible

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The same tendency can be documented among educational researchers and practitioners whohold passionately to underlying assumptions or favored interventions that are un- tested or run counter to the prevailing evidence

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: There is even reason to question what some educators or educational researchers regard as “evidence” in support offavored approaches or emergent interventions, but that issue lies outside the scopeof the current discussion

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Perhaps like others within the educational community, I have harbored the somewhat impish urge to stand up in a public forum and shout “The emperor hasno clothes!” when I encounter these seemingly unwarranted claims or perceptions.Further, I feel strongly that those within the educational research community havean obligation to call the public’s attention to seemingly widespread beliefs or per-ceptions that, at a minimum, demand closer inspection

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It is also essential to turnthat critical eye inward to scrutinize certain popular conceptions that appear withinthe educational discourse

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: I want to expose whatI perceive as insidious educational myths that have been allowed to take root andspread within the realms of public perception and political decision making,maybe even reaching into sectors of the educational community

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: These are beliefsthat cannot continue to infiltrate individual minds or public conscience without theprotection that comes with healthy skepticism or reasonable doubt

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Specifically, I want to discuss six educational myths that I contend are alive and well within public and political arenas—myths that have not been successfully dis- pelled and that, therefore, continue to exert tremendous influence on funded edu- cational research and mandated educational practices

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Achievement on High-Stakes Tests Equals Learning The first myth that I want to expose is the belief that the word achievement, which has come to represent performance on high-stakes tests, equates to the concept oflearning

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In fact, I have arguedelsewhere that effective education requires effective assessment (Alexander, 2006;ACADEMIC DEVELOPMENT 637

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Alexander & Riconscente, 2005), which is defined as the “process of obtaining information that is used to make educational decisions about students, to givefeedback to the student about his or her progress, strengths, weaknesses, to judgeinstructional effectiveness and curricular adequacy, and to inform policy” (Ameri- can Federation of Teachers, National Council of Measurement in Education, & National Educational Association, 1990,p

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: But tests are merely one aspect ofassessment, and tests that result in reliable and valid data are, at best, only mean- ingful samplings of students’ knowledge and capabilities

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Consequently, when the educational system relies solely or almost exclusively on high-stakes tests to es- tablish the worth of its teachers, the effectiveness of its schools, or the attainment of its students, the potential merits of assessment are misunderstood

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: This tendency to equate performance on high-stakes assessments with learning is problematic for a number of other reasons

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It portrays education as a series ofdiscrete hurdles to be cleared rather than as an ongoing journey to be relished

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Inaddition, it is all about the “ends” and not the “means.” That is, test performance isthe goal—not the understanding or knowledge that such tests are sampling

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In es-sence, this orientation colors academic content as information to be garnered inservice of performance, not as knowledge to be sought for personal fulfillment.Further, linking learning to high-stakes tests may promote performance avoidanceversus mastery orientation (Harackiewicz, Barron, & Elliot, 1998; Linnenbrink,2005)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: That means that students work to avoid failure rather than seek to under-stand and master valued academic content

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It is about what they do at that pointon a select measure

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: How far one has progressed or future academic/personal goalsdo not enter into the equation

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Finally, this orientation toward education is “coldlycognitive” (Pintrich, Marx, & Boyle, 1993)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It overlooks critical strategic and mo- tivational factors that are central to academic development

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Of course, it might be argued that the compulsion to let the test drive curriculum may not theoretically be a justifiable decision but that from a practical standpoint itmakes sense, since it would seem to ensure that students at least learn the contentthat is flagged by those tests—the very argument put forth by former PresidentGeorgeW

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The problem is that the empirical evidence brings even that argu- ment into question

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For example, an experiment by Deci, Spiegel, Ryan, Koestner, and Kauffman (1982) showed that students working with teachers who were in- structed to facilitate learning employed more strategies associated with higher aca- demic attainment did better than students whose teachers were told to focus on test standards

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Several years later, Flink, Boggiano, and Barrett (1990) replicated andextended those findings

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: study, teachers told to en- sure that their students perform well on target measures manifested more control- ling instructional strategies and had lower student performance than teachers di- rected to facilitate student learning

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Still other data suggest the flaws inherent in the “teach to the test” curricular mentality (e.g., Grolnick & Ryan, 1987; Ryan &638 ALEXANDER

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It is not only the students who suffer in the current high-stakes test climate

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For ex- ample, Emmet Rosenfeld (2004), a former teacher in Virginia, brought the poten- tial side effects of this test obsession to reality as he discussed the negative influ- ence that the state’s Standards of Learning had on his career: Standards of Learning were introduced to make education better

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The intense pressure to raise test scores eventually squeezed the life out of school, both for my kids and for me.… I no longer loved myjob; at least, I didn’t want to spend the rest of my professional career teaching to astandardized test

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: 20) Accountability Is About Improving Students’ Learning Although I am focusing on the current obsession with high-stakes testing, I want to deal with another myth that interferes with students’ academic development.Throughout the public and political discourse about educational reform, the notionof “accountability” is often conjured as some elixir to heal current ailments

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Whenaccountability is so voiced, it is typically in terms of educational administrators orclassroom teachers who must be held responsible for their students’ performanceon state and national assessments

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Implicit in this rhetoric is the assumption thatthis stress on state, district, or school administrators’ or teachers’ accountabilitywill contribute to improved student learning

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In effect, this presumption amounts to a “trickle-down” philosophy of educa- tional reform

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: But does such a belief hold up under scrutiny—or is this just anotherinstance of educational mythology

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: At the very least, we must acknowledge thatthis persistent emphasis on accountability stands as a symbol of public and politi- cal distrust with the educational system and educational professionals

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In effect, since we cannot trust educational professionals to work for improved studentlearning, we must hold threats over their heads to ensure compliance

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Such an“overseer mentality” dismisses the power of positive reinforcers and rewards toencourage individuals to work under challenging conditions or with learners ingreatest need

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Where are the social, motivational, and financial incentives forthose who consider entering one of the most challenging and significant profes- sions

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: All stick and no carrot! Not much of a motivational plan to recruit outstand- ing candidates into the teaching profession

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Another dimension of this accountability myth is mirrored in the unit of analy- sis central to educational legislation, such as NCLB

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: If accountability were truly about improved student learning over the course of the educational experience,then we would expect the data that come from high-stakes tests to be directly rele- vant to the identification and service of individual students’ academic strengths and needs

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Indeed, if there was more diagnostic merit to these high-stakes tests atACADEMIC DEVELOPMENT 639

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: the level of the individual learner, and if there was more focus on deeper process- ing and more complex thinking, then there would be more reason to devote educa- tional time and money to their development and implementation

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Yet beyond summative judgments of whether students pass or fail, graduate or not, the unit ofanalysis on which programmatic, accountability, and instructional decisions arebased has little to do with individual student learning and development

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: To support this contention, Michelle Riconscente and I examined the language of NCLB to test our hypothesis that the focus was not on learners but on teachersand schools (Alexander & Riconscente, 2005) and that phrases such as “high-achieving schools,” “low-performing schools,” or “schools that excel” dot the leg- islative landscape

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: What we determined in our discourse analysis was that the NCLB legislation used the word “school” almost 4,000 times

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In fact, “individual”was used 10 times less and “student” showed up at half the frequency of “school” orits variants in this legislation

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Regrettably, we must not lose sight of the fundamentalfact that schools do not learn

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Clearly, there is a confounding of measures of overall schoolachievement with those of individual students in the educational mythology

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: However, the choice of assessment must be commensurate with the goals of that assess-ment since certain indicators have value in particular contexts or for certain tasksor student populations but not others (Mislevy, 1994; Pellegrino, Chudowsky, &Glaser, 2001)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: High-stakes assessments that measure broad content knowledgeare often ineffective tools for diagnosing student learning or guiding instruc- tional decision making (Braun & Mislevy, 2004)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: When the academic develop- ment of students moves to the foreground, the characteristics of those students, along with features of the task and the context, are raised to a higher status,thereby allowing for more valid inferences about learning (Baxter, Elder, &Glaser, 1996; Mislevy, 1994)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Mentioning Equals Teaching Even in the pre-NCLB days, when I was teaching public school, I remember the pressure to cover the content, that is, the feeling that I had to ensure that my stu- dents were at least exposed to all the knowledge and skills specified in the district’s scope and sequence chart

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Covering the content haslong been de rigueur for practicing teachers required to deal with far too much content in far too short a time span

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Moreover, I remain greatly concerned that thisdrive to get through the material in today’s classrooms comes at great cost to aca-640 ALEXANDER

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Like many educators, it had not occurred to me that this men- tioning was a poor proxy for the teaching of which I knew I was capable

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Men- tioning simply does not allow teachers or their students to delve deeply and meaningfully into important academic content

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It is Dolores Durkin (1978–1979) who is credited with coining the term men- tioning

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Durkin, investigating the deplorable lack of comprehension instruction, referred to mentioning as the superficial treatment of essential concepts and strate- gies

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Viewed in this manner, mentioning may promote an “illusion of teaching” among educators, as well as an “illusion of learning” on the part of students (Alex- ander & Knight, 1993)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Thus, educators must recognize that even repeated men- tioning of key academic content does not ensure that learning will occur

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: That is why others have called for teaching more about less (diSessa, 1993)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: This counter- point to mentioning (which entails teaching less and less about more and more) may allow educators the time they need to teach

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: However, it does not address thefundamental question of what content ultimately merits such valuable instruc- tional focus

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: To do that one must ascertain the underlying principles that define disciplines and domains and determine how those foundational principles can beintroduced, honed, and elaborated over the course of students’ academic develop-ment

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Such principles are much more foundational understand-ings than the multitude of concepts and skills that constitute typical schoolcurricula

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: These principles are, in effect, the premises that define a domain or dis-cipline and distinguish it from yet another domain or discipline

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For instance, edu-cational experiences should assist students to understand the nature of historicalthinking and facilitate their capacity to gather and analyze relevant historical evi-dence (Maggioni, VanSledright, & Alexander, 2009)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: They should also supportstudents’ acquisition of the strategies required to pose and test hypotheses aboutthe physical world in science and to interrogate texts while reading in order toachieve a deep comprehension of the encrypted message (Alexander et al., inpress; Fox & Alexander, 2009)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Effective Education Will Eliminate Student Differences Another persistent belief that works against the realization of academic develop- ment is the myth that effective education can somehow eliminate learner differ- ences

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: I first became aware of this myth as a new assistant professor

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: At a college meeting, a well-intentioned administrator came to the podium to share departmen- tal initiatives

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In the excitement of the moment, this individual stated that his de- partment’s professional development activities would succeed in leveling the aca- demic playing field for allstudents

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The implication of his message was that the better the instruction, the more equality in student learning and achievement wouldbe evidenced

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: get started that great education would bring about academic parity at the level of the individual student

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Sadly, it is not just this one well-intentioned but misguidedprofessor who gives credence to the myth that effective education will eliminateindividual differences

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Before I proceed, let me clarify that I am talking about the mythology surround- ingindividual differences, not group differences

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: There is every reason to view the disparity between particular groups as real and unacceptable (Lee, 2002)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: How- ever, the rhetoric does not stop at the group but permeates to the level of the indi- vidual learner

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In the Statement of Purpose, it is claimed that NCLB’s purpose of ensuringthat “all children have a fair, equal, and significant opportunity to obtain ahigh-quality education and reach, at a minimum, proficiency on challenging Stateacademic achievement standards and state academic assessments” (p

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: 15) can beaccomplished by “closing the achievement gap between high- and low-performingchildren, especially the achievement gaps between minority and nonminority stu- dents, and between disadvantaged children and their more advantaged peers” (p

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Thus, even within the federal legislation, there is the notion that effective edu- cation can indeed close “the achievement gap between high- and low-performingchildren,” as the wording of NCLB suggests

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Despite such well-intentionedphraseology, the reality, I would contend, is to the contrary

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: That is to say, we cannever eliminate individual differences that exist within all groups, be they minority or nonminority, economically advantaged or disadvantaged

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Moreover, as I arguehere, effective education will not only fail to eliminate differences that exist be-tween learners but will also serve to exacerbate such differences

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For one, there hasbeen more than a century of research on the variability that exists at the level of theindividual with regard to an array of cognitive, affective, and motivational factorsthat influence student learning

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Students inevitably bring these differences into theacademic environment, and their effects on learning and development can be tre- mendous

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Unless human variability can be excised, any expectations of academic “sameness” implied by this myth remain invalid

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Let me again make it clear that Iam not discussing inequities or disparities that currently exist between cultural andsocioeconomic groups

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: More to the point, there is reason to assume that effective instruction could po- tentially exacerbate human differences that exist rather than eliminate them

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: This assumption is supported by the research on the Matthew effect (Stanovich, 1986).Keith Stanovich named this effect for its literary reference to Matthew 25:29: “Forunto every one that hath shall be given, and he shall have abundance: but from himthat hath not shall be taken away even that which he hath.” What Stanovich pro- posed is that students who are cognitively, affectively, or motivationally richer get642 ALEXANDER

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Conversely, those who enter their academic experiences with limited cognitive and motivational re- sources face the prospect of falling further and further behind their more privileged classmates

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Learning environments will, consequently, not be experienced equallyby students as a consequence of preexisting differences in their knowledge, strate- gic abilities, motivations, and cognitive capabilities

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The individual differences that preexist any educational experience ensure that variability in learning will re- sult from those experiences

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The Purpose of Formal Education Is Clear One might assume from the intense concentration of fiscal and human resources on current programmatic and assessment efforts that the most fundamental educa- tional issues—the reason that the social institutions of schools exist and the pur- pose of the formal education they provide—have been resolved

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: However, I would argue that either we have failed to weigh these most basic questions orwe have failed to consider that content and processes of current edu- cational practices in light of our beliefs

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The bottom line is the tacit acceptance thatthe purpose of education is clear and well established

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In truth, one might have un-told purposes for participating in formal education

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For example, is the purpose ofeducation, as Malcolm Forbes (n.d.) stated, to “replace an empty mind with anopen one”

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Or is it “the progressive discovery of our own ignorance,” as the histo-rian Will Durant (n.d.) so eloquently said

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Maybe, like John Dewey (1897), oneconceives of education as “a social process … a process of living and not a prepa- ration for future living” (p

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: 10), the function of education “is to teach one to think intensively and to think critically.” Prophetically, King warned that“education which stops with efficiency may prove the greatest menace to society.The most dangerous criminal may be the man gifted with reason, but with no mor- als.” From a more pragmatic and legalistic standpoint, the Supreme Court in Yoderv

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Wisconsin (1972) ruled that the purpose of education is to prevent citizens from becoming a burden on the state

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Yet even from this less lofty vantage point, itwould appear that the educational system has failed for far too many of the popu- lace

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: However, do we see any of these laudable or pragmatic purposes reflected in current educational policies or assessment practices

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Where is the depth of explo- ration of self or domains of knowledge implied by these declarations (Deci et al., 1982; diSessa, 1993)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Where is the concern for thinking intensively or critically(e.g., Alexander et al., in press)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: I see little in the current educational policies and as- sessment that portray a clear educational purpose beyond the acquisition of the most basic skills in threshold domains.ACADEMIC DEVELOPMENT 643

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The Social and Motivational Aspects of Education Are Well Understood In their analysis of the research base for the American Psychological Association’s learner-centered principles, Alexander and Murphy (1998) stated that the socio- cultural context and motivational/affective forces play a significant role in stu- dents’ learning and development

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: A wealth of research from social psychology, school psychology, educational psychology, and other fields has established thatmany noncognitive factors that operate in schools and in out-of-school environ- ments can serve to foster or frustrate students’ academic development (Pintrich et al., 1993)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For instance, students who have low self-esteem or low efficacy beliefs;students without social supports in school or at home; or students who are bored,disaffected, or generally unengaged cannot be expected to realize their academicpotential (Csikszentmihalyi, 1991)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Nonetheless, when we consider the focus ofteacher preparation, policy initiatives, or curricular interventions, it would appearthat the educational experience is largely conceptualized and operationalized as a“coldly cognitive” enterprise (Pintrich et al., 1995)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: If academic development is to be fully embraced, it will be critical to address multiple dimensions of students’ lives—from their physical care to their socialwell-being—even as we strive to expand their minds and enrich their knowledgeand cognitive capabilities

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: There should also be systematic consideration of howthe educational experience influences motivational and affective conditions, alongwith the cognitive outcomes that are commonplace

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For example, there are reasonsto be concerned about the long-term effects of non-engaging reading programs onstudents’ motivations toward reading (Guthrie & Wigfield, 1997) and about agrowing dislike of mathematics that is seemingly associated with “drill-and-kill”pedagogical approaches (Meece, Wigfield, & Eccles, 1990; Middleton & Spanias,1999)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It is not simply a matter of how noncognitive factors shape students’ learning and development

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: How the educational experience influences students socially,culturally, motivationally, and affectively is also of concern

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: I wish I could say thatthe centuries of educational research and practice have resulted in a clear picture ofthe cognitive and affective transformations that should occur in students as theyparticipate in the formal educational process

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: There is research sug- gesting that motivation begins to wane as students progress through school (Wigfield, Tonks, & Eccles, 2004)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Evidence of diminished engagement, in- creased boredom, and learner apathy has also been reported (e.g., Riconscente, 2007)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Of course, no one program or intention can hope to do it all

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The scope andcomplexity of the problem is simply too much for any one empirical study, evenone that is longitudinal in design

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: However, at a minimum, we should expect thatinterventions that speak to academic development at an individual level considernoncognitive variables.644 ALEXANDER

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: THE MDL I would like to offer up one modest program of research that I have pursued over the past 10 years and that has sought to investigate academic development in termsof students’ learning in academic domains

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: My approach to studying academic de- velopment is the MDL, in which my goal was to document the systematic changes that occur in learners as they progress toward increased competence within recog- nized fields of study (e.g., Alexander, 1997; Alexander, Jetton, & Kulikowich, 1995; Alexander, Murphy, Woods, Duhon, & Parker, 1997; Murphy & Alexander,2002)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The interplay between three central constructs (i.e., knowledge, strategicprocessing, and interest), each investigated in two varied forms (i.e., domain andtopic knowledge, surface-level strategies and deep-processing strategies, and indi- vidual interest and situational interest), serves as the backbone of the MDL

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Based on decades of prior research on these constructs, individually and in combination(e.g., Alexander & Judy, 1988; de Jong & Ferguson-Hessler, 1986; Dewey, 1913;Hidi, 1990), I formulated a model as to what changes should transpire in their in-terrelations should individuals show growth toward increased competence andperhaps even expertise in a specific academic domain

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Thus, as depicted in Figure 1, it was hypothesized that those in the earliest stage of their domain-specific development (i.e., acclimation) have both limited andfragmented domain (breadth) or topic (depth) knowledge upon which they candraw

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In part because of the state of their knowledge, students in acclimation alsohave to use many surface-level strategies that allow them to make sense of the do-main-specific problems they confront, and they are less able to delve into deep-processing strategies that allow them to transform or deeply ponder the current sit-uation

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Furthermore, this lack of rich domain knowledge and the high strategic de- mands are complicated by a lack of deep-seated interest in or personal identifica- tion with the domain or a given domain-specific task (i.e., individual interest)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Rather, learners in acclimation rely on features of the task or the context to piquetheir interest and motivate their engagement (i.e., situational interest)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: If conditions are favorable and the suitable educational experiences are forth- coming, learners can cross the threshold into competence—and thankfully most students who have the benefit of a K–12 education can achieve at least fragile com- petence in most basic academic domains (e.g., reading, mathematics, history)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: In effect, competence is an extended stage that is marked by quantitative and qualita- tive changes in knowledge, strategic processing, and interest

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For instance, topic and domain knowledge not only increases, but that knowledge becomes more co- hesive or more principled, which is a hallmark of this stage

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: What is also dramatic and related to this quantitative and qualitative shift in domain knowledge withincompetence is that learners manifest more deep-processing strategies and a risingpersonal interest in the domain

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Toward mid-level competence, this investment inthe domain becomes a compelling force that is marked by individuals’ intentionalACADEMIC DEVELOPMENT 645

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: pursuit of knowledge and experiences related to the field, a transformational process we have documented in the words and actions of competent learners in such diversedomains as reading and history (Fox & Dinsmore, 2009; Maggioni et al., 2009)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: For the relatively rare percentage of individuals who reach the stage of profi- ciency or expertise, their domain and topic knowledge is understandably exten- sive

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Even more indicative of their expertise is that these individuals are expected to be engaged in activities that contribute new knowledge and understandings tothe domain

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: This transformational knowledge comes about, in part, because theseindividuals are truly engrossed in and self-identify with the domain

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Further, theirinterest helps them strategically engage in problem finding and problem cre- ation—an engagement that is extensively deep-processing in character

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It is cru- cial to note that these attributes of proficiency or expertise cannot be realistically achieved within the confines of typical K–16 education

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Nonetheless, the foundations for exper- tise must be established during these formative years and should be reflected in the goals and experiences that compose K–16 education.646 ALEXANDER FIGURE 1 A representation of the changing relation of domain and topic knowledge, sur- face-level and deep-processing strategies, and individual and situational interest over the stagesof the model of domain learning.

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: The evidence we have gathered from young students to renowned experts has provided support for the MDL in a range of domains, from biology, astrophysics,and history to reading, educational psychology, and special education (e.g., Alex- ander, Kulikowich, & Schulze, 1994)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Others researchers have found the MDL worthy of exploration as well and have put the predictions of the model to the testin such domains as physical education, social studies, engineering, technology,and music therapy (e.g., Chen, Shen, Scrabis, & Tolley, 2002; Lawless & Kuli- kowich, 1998; VanSledright, 2002)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: What these data suggest is that academic de- velopment is a promising way to consider the long-term, continuous influence of cognitive and motivational factors on learners and learning

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Yet there is muchmore to be done to test the MDL and to allow for fuller exploration of changes overtime within domains and disciplines, that is, to inform understanding of academicdevelopment

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Clearly, longitudinal studies that reveal the orchestrated changes in these cogni- tive and noncognitive forces are necessary, along with studies that explore critical transition periods in the lives of learners at varying ages and in varying socioculturalcontexts

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: We are also concerned with how one first gets a solid foothold in a domain,as in the emergence of children’s individual interest (Jablonski & Alexander, 2009)or the manner in which intentionality drives development even in the face of strug-gles or setbacks (Kulikowich & Alexander, 2009)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: We are also working diligently touncover more precise but less intrusive measures of strategic processing (Fox & Al-exander, 2009)

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Although there is much work to be done and far more interdisciplin-ary inquiry to be initiated, we remain excited about the prospects of discoveringmore about the nature of human domain learning in the years to come

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Again, this work on the MDL represents just one examination of academic de- velopment

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: It is by no means the only or best approach to investigating academicdevelopment

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Thus, we look forward to many other investigations into the multi- tude of factors, situations, or contexts that can illuminate the nature of this intrigu- ing construct and guide us in fostering optimal development for all who walk through the doors of our schools in hopes of becoming well educated

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: As did thelate Robert Gagné (1977), we remain committed to helping students become morecompetent and more capable of adjusting to the complexities of life in a post- industrial society, not only so that they may survive but also so that they may “find a satisfying quality to their lives” (p

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: MOVING BEYOND THE MYTHOLOGY What I have endeavored to show is that we can no longer allow the educational mythos to survive if we truly intend for formal schooling to set learners on a pathtoward optimal learning and development

TITLE: Through Myth to Reality- Reframing Education as Academic Development
SENTENCE: Even though the minimum criteria for a“free and appropriate education” have still to be realized for many, they simply doACADEMIC DEVELOPMENT 647

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In our use of the term theoretical perspective, we are acknowl- edging that broad orientations to learning are instantiated by particular models and theories offering mechanisms of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Our focus is most often on how the broad cat-egories, or perspectives, fare in the criterial evaluation to which we put them

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The accomplishment of our overarching intention was predicated on the completion of four speciﬁc and interrelated tasks

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Therefore, we ﬁrst articulate principles of learning, ac- ceptable to those holding multiple theoretical perspectives,and basic to a viable conceptualization of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Second, we position four dimensions of learning within an interactive framework that can serve as a basis for judging the com-prehensiveness and potential viability of current and future theoretical perspectives and empirical investigations

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Third, having considered these common principles and interactivedimensions, we forward a working deﬁnition of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Last, we present three exemplars to illustrate the way in which the interactive dimensions of learning dynamically unfold in everyday instances of human learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: It is important to consider the value of this endeavor be- fore we initiate these tasks

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: One apparent value is to bring the notion of learning into the realm of explicit discourse so that we may contemplate the construct more deeply

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Although itwould be convenient if the nature of learning were well estab- lished thereby requiring no detailed explication, we contend that there is no such clear consensus and that a thoughtful,critical look at the very nature of learning is beneﬁcial, both for those just entering the ﬁeld and for those more deeply invested in the domain

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In this article, we want to highlighthow conceptualizations of learning, whether expressed or not, shape everyday decisions that have import in our lives

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In addition, it is easy to read the research literature as implying that each professed view on learning is fully ade- quate and thus requires no further justiﬁcation

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Such views, we suggest, have underestimated the complexity of learningand led to a disregard for competing notions and to a frac- turing of the community along theoretical fault lines

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Such parochialism and fracturing can contribute to a balkanization of the ﬁeld, an unproductive breakdown in willingness to en- tertain alternative frameworks beyond the level of caricature.This lack of theoretical comity within education and psychol- ogy as to the nature of learning has been noted (Alexander, 1997; Eisner, 1997; Mayer, 2001; Reynolds, Sinatra, & Jet-ton, 1996; Schallert & Martin, 2003)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Indeed, contrasting and contentious views of learning dot the educational landscape and hinder progress in this domain for researchers and practi-tioners alike

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Nonetheless, because learning remains core to educational and psychological (e.g., cognitive, motivational, and emotional) endeavors despite its problematic and elusivenature, we consider it worthwhile to search for a way to frame the problem differently

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Our proposal is that the seemingly irreconcilable differ- ences among theoretical perspectives arise largely from theirspeciﬁc position in the learning landscape and the vista on learning that each position affords

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: This is not to say that all such perspectives are equally defensible

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Rather, we at- tempt to demonstrate that their differences may arise from de- fending quite different locales within the learning landscape.Such views as espoused by cognitive contextualists (Ander- son, 1977; Bransford, 1979; Piaget, 1926; Spiro, Vispoel, Schmitz, Samarapungavan, & Boerger, 1987), sociocultural-ists (Anderson et al., 2001; Schoultz,S ¨alj¨o, & Wyndhamn, 2001; Vygotsky, 1978; Wertsch & Kanner, 1992), cognitive- evolutionist researchers (Donald, 1991; Geary, 2005; Pinker,2002; Plotkin, 1998), and situativists (Cobb, 1994; Cole & Engstr ¨om, 1993; Greeno & van de Sande, 2007), among others, give us an invaluable but limited view of learning’ slandscape

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Speciﬁcally, our approach is to propose a topo- graphical framework for the learning system that allows us to pinpoint more accurately contemporary theories and modelson the basis of their attention to essential dimensions of learn- ing

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Once positioned within this multidimensional space, we can then undertake a more thoughtful analysis of the theories and models not only in terms of their conceptualization of learning but also their ability to capture particular facets ofthe learning system in valid and reliable ways

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: FINDING COMMON GROUND When the three of us began our analysis, we were aware that through a long history of involvement in this domain, almost a century cumulatively, we had developed afﬁnities for theo-retical perspectives that perceive learning from diverse, and sometimes even seemingly incommensurate, vantage points

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Despite good intentions to set aside personal agendas andtheoretical perspectives and to achieve a shared understand- ing, we found that differences in our conceptualizations of learning quickly asserted themselves and became barriers toprogress, even threatening to scuttle the enterprise

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For that reason, we determined that any hope for success required that we ﬁrst seek common ground, a basis from which subsequentdelineations could emerge

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In essence, we sought consilience, a term introduced by Whewell (1840) and used by Wilson (1998) to describe unity of knowledge across varied disci-plines

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We appropriated the term to refer to our efforts to ﬁnd commonality across varied perspectives on learning in the same ﬁeld

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Throughout, we focused expressly on human learning, acknowledging that aspects of the common ground we were seeking might well apply to other living organisms

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: A surprising by-product of this initial theoretical compact was that the common ground we sought took the form of principles and, more important, principles foundational tothe nature of human learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We appreciate that the sim- plicity of the language we use and the brevity of the points expressed may unintentionally mask the signiﬁcance of theprinciples we forward

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: It is conceivable that those long en- gaged in the study of learning may be tempted to dismiss

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: 178 ALEXANDER, SCHALLERT, REYNOLDS this collection of principles as givens, or as commonsense or well-established axioms of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: First, for all our years and investment in this domain, we are not aware of any explication of the nature of learning that captures all thepoints articulated herein

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Further, what may seem common- sense to experts in learning and learning theory cannot be treated as such by those who are either new to the domainor whose expertise does not fall directly under the banner of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Finally, to those who would see our principles as self-evident, we point to the late Nate Gage’s (1991) seminalessay titled “The Obviousness of Social and Educational Re- search Results,” in which such impressions were frequently shown to be untrustworthy

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: With this caveat in place, we now turn to the resulting nine principles: rPrinciple 1 Learning is changerPrinciple 2 Learning is inevitable, essential, and ubiqui- tousrPrinciple 3 Learning can be resistedrPrinciple 4 Learning may be disadvantageousrPrinciple 5 Learning can be tacit and incidental as well as conscious and intentionalrPrinciple 6 Learning is framed by our humannessrPrinciple 7 Learning refers to both a process and a prod- uctrPrinciple 8 Learning is different at different points in timerPrinciple 9 Learning is interactional Principle 1: Learning Is Change A fundamental characteristic of what it means for humans to learn is that change happens

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: This notion of change ap- plies whether the focus is on simpler learning of physical movements (e.g., skipping on one foot) or more complexlearning of abstract principles (e.g., understanding the al- legorical nature of the American classic Moby-Dick)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For instance, change may be seen as the development of socialpractices in individuals or groups, or change may be regarded as altered conceptions that arise from person–environment interactions

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Alternatively, change might be understood asarising from the evolved, innate processing capacities of the human brain/mind and the adaptive nature inherent in human beings or as being driven by stages of physiological matu- ration

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Indeed, there are no current conceptions of learning that do not include the notion of change, either explicitly orimplicitly

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: First, the change that happens can range from the dramatic to the almost imperceptible

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Second, change canoccur over inﬁnite scales of time; it can occur in an instant or transpire over expanses of time

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In effect, just as a river sculpts aspects of thelandscape, even as aspects of the landscape shape the river, change that happens in the learner, be it dramatic or imper-ceptible, or immediate or gradual, exerts a reciprocal effect on the learner’s surroundings

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Principle 2: Learning Is Inevitable, Essential, and Ubiquitous Being alive means being a learner

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Being alive for humans brings with it the inevitability of learning, as well as its ne- cessity

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In effect, one cannot prevent learning from occurring(inevitable), nor can one hope to survive unless learning hap- pens (essential)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Moreover, learning is not relegated to any singular physical or cultural environment, but unfolds wher-ever humans move in the world (ubiquitous)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Indeed, learning is a biological imperative for human beings; so much so that most of learning happens automatically and is not under theconscious control of the learner (Bargh & Chartrand, 1999; Norman, 1968; Reber, 1989)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In his commentary on human memory, Flavell (1971) asserted that children do not need tobe taught how to remember; memory happens

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Humans are evolved learners, and through matu- ration and experience, certain aspects of learning becomeseemingly effortless and below the level of consciousness, whereas other aspects become more complex, differentiated, and demand conscious effort (Bransford, Brown, & Cocking, 1999)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Although educational researchers and practitioners regularly invest attention on forms of higher order learning,it is important to remember that learning also encompasses these less apparent, yet critical, forms of learning (Reynolds, 2000)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Although the learning of nonhuman animals has received much atten- tion from researchers, particularly in the ﬁrst half of the 20thcentury, it is not difﬁcult to gain consensus on the point that humans are fascinating examples of learning systems (es- pecially to other humans)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: What makes humans fascinatingas learners is that they enter the world in such a helpless state but possess innate abilities that avail them of the op- portunity to acquire understandings and procedures over arelatively short period

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Such innate capacities coupled with environmental and contextual affordances permit humans to navigate even arduous social and physical terrains

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Learning is ubiquitous, applying in all sorts of situations and in all sorts of environments

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Even though we are prone to conceive of learning as nested in schools and associate it with formal educational systems and procedures, learningwill not be so delimited

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The processes of learning are in operation whenever and wherever humans are situated

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Principle 3: Learning Can Be Resisted As inevitable, essential, and ubiquitous as learning is, a curi- ous corollary is that there are instances when humans resistlearning (and the change it implies), even ﬁnding it painful

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: LEARNING TOPOGRAPHY 179 there are many times when we learn in spite of ourselves

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Why are we sometimes so reluctant to engage in the effort required to learn a new way of thinking or acting even when the goal is desirable

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: It could well be that the effort required is judged as too great, or the rewardstoo small (Kahneman, 1973; Wigﬁeld & Eccles, 2000), or the likelihood of success deemed too risky for learning to be pursued

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Or it is possible that the attainment of the desiredgoal might create dissonance within the individual or par- ticular social system that cannot be tolerated

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Thus, it often happens that opportunities for changing deeply held or ha-bitual ways of interacting with the world are sometimes, at least initially, circumvented, resisted, or denied

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Conceived in this manner, this principle of learning embraces much of thetheoretical and empirical work within the literatures on con- ceptual change (e.g.,V osniadou, 2003) and epistemic beliefs (e.g., Murphy & Mason, 2006)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Principle 4: Learning May Be Disadvantageous It seems clear that learning results in changes that are not always advantageous to self or others.Y et, because the con- struct of learning has such positive connotations, it may be important to make this principle explicit

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We cannot limit learning only to what is valued, accepted, or acceptable

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Here we must clarify that the notion of advantageous or disadvantageous that we posit has two valid interpreta- tions

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: On one hand, there is the learning that happens whensomeone has learned something that he or she wishes had never been learned (e.g., smoking or howp ˆat´ed efo i egr as is made)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: On the other hand, there is the learning that is utile and satisfying to the person (and perhaps a group of like- minded individuals), but disadvantageous and undesirable tosome broader social group (e.g., excessive online gaming)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Although the more positive and advantageous outcomes of learning are what may be sought, the learning system doesnot discriminate

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Principle 5: Learning Can Be Tacit and Incidental as Well as Conscious and Intentional Much (perhaps most) learning happens outside the realm of conscious control or intentionality (Epstein, 2001; Polanyi,1966); hence, much of learning is tacit and incidental

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Often learners cannot give an explicit rendering of when learningoccurred, how learning happened, or how they were changed

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Even in the classroom where academic development is the business at hand, much of learning lives in the water table be- low the surface

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: What proportion of learning is tacit remains open to debate; Bargh and Chartrand (1999) suggested thatas much as 90% of all learning is implicit

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Whatever the pro- portion is, we would agree that, just as in the physical world, there is much below the surface of learning’s landscape

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For example, a student learning the concept of solving for an unknown in an algebraic equation is learning mathemat- ical ideas, and we would say this is the student’s intentionaltask

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: However, at the same time, the student is learning the language of algebra with its peculiar vocabulary, symbolic representations, and syntactic constructions, as well as thesocial practices that this algebra classroom prefers, such as how solutions should look on paper or how homework pages should be stapled

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Turning to out-of-school examples, wewant to point to the largely unconscious and incidental na- ture of ﬁrst language acquisition and of motor development, where in both domains the interaction of environment and in- nate human wiring results in particularly suitable outcomes (Chomsky, 1957; Clark, 1994; Wells, 1987)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Moreover, evenwhen acquisition was initially effortful and conscious, subse- quent use of that learning can be unconscious and automatic

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Language is again a great example as when individuals auto-matically deploy what they know about words and the syntax of their language even as their conscious focus is on how to express what they want to say

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Principle 6: Learning Is Framed by Our Humanness Our humanness plays a critical role in how we learn and what we learn

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Here we are primarily referring to the contri- bution of the particular neurobiological architecture humans have developed

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Spock, we are “carbon-based” life-forms whose neurological structures shape the nature of how the world is experienced and whose senses are conduits for interacting with the world and withothers who populate that world

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Those senses are particu- lar in structure for our species and limited in range

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Their evolved structure and the environment that has surroundedthem across time restrict our senses and cognitive processes

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Consequently, the colors we see, the tones we hear, the smells we can detect, and the nature of our reasoning are all con- strained by our evolved biology

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: It is not just that our neurological and biological bases frame the processes and products of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Even within the range of human possibilities, there is variability with which we must contend

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Just as some of us are taller orfaster than others, some of us have greater visual acuity, or memory capacity, or facility with language than others

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Indeed, there can be signiﬁcant differences among individ-uals with regard to any cognitive or noncognitive factor

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: 180 ALEXANDER, SCHALLERT, REYNOLDS boundaries within which learning may be constrained in the human system

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Thus, just as our evolved biology—that which makes us human—must be embraced in any model or theory of learning, so too must the differences that manifest at the level of the individual be recognized

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Principle 7: Learning Refers to Both a Process and a Product Descriptions of learning frequently toggle between portray- ing learning as a process, as a set of operations progressing through time, and depicting it as an end-product of that pro-cess, much like a chemical substance is produced when ele- ments are combined

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: When we think of learning as a process, we are focusing on the time course of operations resultingin relatively durable changes

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: When we consider learning as product, we are referring to the relatively durable change that results when learning has occurred, as when new ideas orprocedures have been internalized or memories accumulated as a result of experiences in the physical world or in the world of the mind

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Where learning as process refers to the change as it is taking place, learning as product refers to the outcome of that process

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Formal measures of learning are almost always about learning as product—the consequences of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Although it is perhaps unfortunate that the same word refersto a progressive action and a gerundial noun and may lead to misinterpretations that pivot exactly on this difference, it is our contention that any comprehensive rendering of learn-ing must regard this construct as both process and product

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Indeed, research in which the focus is only on learning as a product may oversimplify our conception of the learningprocess

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The same applies to research in which process is all that is considered

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Principle 8: Learning Is Different at Different Points in Time Because learning is a process, change transpires in time and over time, and leads one to focus on the dynamic ﬂux of factors affecting the beginning, middle, and late stages of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The learning process itself is affected by where thelearner is in a progression to increasing expertise and acqui- sition of knowledge in a domain

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: This developmental view of learning is tied in part to the neurological and biological changes that come with age (Bjorklund & Pellegrini, 2002)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
