SENTENCE: We learn differently at different ages, and the process oflearning changes, reﬂecting the accumulation of experiences that give rise to more complex understandings and more intri- cate relationships among individuals or the relations betweenperson and environment (Bereiter, 2002; Wentzel, 1999)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As mature individuals, we cannot draw aside the veil of life ex- periences to see the world as we did in our childhood

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Wemay seek to “remember” what we thought or felt, but those memories are never replications or duplications.This phenomenon occurs in part because of the recursive and iterative nature of learning; processes result in prod- ucts that in turn inﬂuence subsequent processes

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: An often- cited example can be found in the Matthew effect (Stanovich, 1986), which, simply stated, refers to when a learning prod-uct (e.g., graphophonemic knowledge that underlies rapid and accurate word recognition) interacts with the process of learning (e.g., comprehending), what Stanovich called a re- ciprocal causation effect

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Those with decoding facility read more and hence acquire more background knowledge, which in turn leads to better understanding of future informationand more reading, and so on

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Principle 9: Learning Is Interactional When we assert that learning is interactional, we are high- lighting that learning engages an intermutual sequence of op- erations that are shaped by human culture and biology, amonga host of such inﬂuences, and by how humans act and react to a dynamically changing world

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: All serious discussions of learning would agree that the world “out there” matters tohow learning takes place, although there might be debate in how to construe that world (Bereiter, 1994; Stanovich, 2000)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Moreover, any postbehaviorist learning perspective includes in its description of the interactive nature of learning, the iter- ative coinﬂuences between current and past constructions orrepresentations

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In this interactional mix, continual change occurs not only to learners, but to the context in which learn- ing is embedded as well

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Learners are inﬂuenced by, and atthe same time push back, take from, change, control, and create the environment in which learning is situated

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: FRAMING THE NATURE OF LEARNING Embedded in the nine principles of learning are characteris- tics that stand as salient attributes of this complex but elu- sive construct

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The careful deﬁnition of core constructs is certainly a necessary step in any effort to formulate theory,build models, or conduct investigations; yet more is required

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In theory and research, conceptualization and operationaliza- tion must go hand and hand

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Thus, although the principlesof learning help us answer the question “What is learning,” they cannot help us answer the question of whether an ex- isting perspective of learning is fully speciﬁed or of whether a particular attempt to engineer learning represents a viable operationalization of the construct

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: What is also requiredare criteria that will allow us to judge the manner in which core constructs are theorized, modeled, or empirically inves- tigated

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Toward that end, we offer the dimensions of learningas components in an interactive framework

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Speciﬁcally, we assert that any comprehensive theoretical perspective of learning should be constituted of at least fourdimensions that are continuously interwoven and interactive, represented by the what,where,who, and when of learning.

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: LEARNING TOPOGRAPHY 181 As we seek to demonstrate, although there may well be other features to the learning system that merit consideration in a speciﬁc instantiation of learning, these four dimensions should be viewed as primary (i.e., necessary)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Although we describe each dimension separately, the interactional per-spective represented by Principle 9 holds that learning in- volves the continual interplay of multiple dimensions at any point or under any circumstance

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Indeed, we describe ourrendering of this emergent framework for learning as topo- graphical precisely because we think the interplay among these four dimensions results in a shape to learning that isﬂuid and dynamic, but that also gives rise to discernible and predictable patterns that are multiply determined

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We acknowledge that current contrasting views of learn- ing attend to one or more of these dimensions, however tac- itly.Y et it is also our contention that no existing perspective of which we are aware has explicitly addressed all four ofthese dimensions in any systemic manner

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Rather, what we have determined is that current theoretical orientations cen- ter on certain dimensions, such as the who and what or the who and where dimensions, without due consideration for other equally important facets

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Certainly, extant theoreticalperspectives on learning have not dealt with the time di- mension, the when, in the innovative way that we do

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We support this contention by demonstrating how seemingly op-positional views can be subsumed within our broader four- dimensional framework largely because they are seeking to explain learning from different vantage points within thismultidimensional space

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Moreover, because much of the emphases within existing theoretical perspectives resides at the juncture of person–environment (i.e., the who–where connection), we have cho- sen to begin discussion with the what of learning and con- clude with the when of learning, dimensions of seemingly less import in extant accounts

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In our presentation of the interactive framework, we consider how distinctions among orientations that might be seen as incommensurate outsidethe purview of our topographical framework can more accu- rately be depicted as differential positions within the vector space created by the what,where,who, and when dimensions

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Dimension 1: The What of Learning A comprehensive rendering of learning must give due consid- eration to the objects or foci of that dynamic system (Gius- sani, 1995)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: There is always a what that is being learned or that is in the process of change

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Further, there is am- ple evidence that the objects of learning are distinguishable and classiﬁable, and that those differences are signiﬁcantin how the process of learning unfolds

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For our purposes, we propose that the whats of learning can be well repre- sented as different levels ranging from acquired habits andconditioned responses, to spontaneous concepts and action sequences learned in everyday informal interactions with the FIGURE 1 A representation of interactive complexiﬁcation as per- taining to the what of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: world, to scientiﬁc concepts and practices that are often the result of formal education, as illustrated in Figure 1

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: These levels are formed from the interplay of various fac- tors implicated in the learning process

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Those factors, which can systemically vary in degree (e.g., intensity, frequency, ormagnitude), include but are not limited to the degree to which enculturation into a particular social practice is required, or the degree to which conscious effort is needed, or the degreeof abstraction or complexity involved

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: What distinguishes the levels of learning to which we refer is the extent to which their attainment depends on a particular interplay of thesesalient factors

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Because we feared that using an existing term from the ﬁeld might carry with it inappropriate connotations, we coined the term interactive complexiﬁcation to refer to the conﬂuence of factors that give rise to the increasing intricacy of any given aspect of the products or processes (i.e., the whats) of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We appreciate that there may be other systems of clas- sifying the what of learning that rely on other features or mechanisms than our own interactive complexiﬁcation; wit- ness Spiro’s (with Feltovich, Jacobson, & Coulson, 1992) insightful identiﬁcation of important differences betweenwell-structured and ill-structured domains

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We do not view these alternatives as problematic, provided that they are jus- tiﬁed and defensible

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Rather, our critical point here is thattheoretical perspectives must take account of the differing objects of learning in some manner and not treat learning as a unitary process or outcome

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For instance, it is not our goalto support or refute behaviorism as a theory of learning but rather to argue that certain premises underlying a behavior

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: 182 ALEXANDER, SCHALLERT, REYNOLDS theory perspective are easier to understand and apply if one stays within the realm of acquired habits

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: When behaviorism meanders away from this familiar terrain, it is far less sustain- able, as the history of psychology has so clearly demonstrated (Robins, Gosling, & Craik, 1999)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Of course, the same ar-gument can be directed toward any other theory of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Our contention is that certain conﬂicts between stances on learning rest on their disregard of this very concern

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Given this understanding and prior to describing attributes and characteristics of the ﬁrst level, acquired habits and con- ditionings, we want to acknowledge that all learning has as itsfoundation a biological and neurological basis (as represented by the base of the helix in Figure 1)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Inborn reﬂexes, abilities, and capacities are initiating points for future physical, cog-nitive, and psychosocial development

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Whereas such inborn reﬂexes, abilities, and capacities are not themselves learned, they represent the primordial matter from which learningemerges over time and space and, in fact, remain inﬂuential across the levels

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: This continuing inﬂuence is depicted as the axis of the helix in Figure 1

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Consider, for example, what might qualify as inborn re- ﬂexes, abilities, and capacities for the domain of reading—adomain with which we are intimately familiar

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For one, we might regard certain perceptual and visual processes, such as the ability to discriminate light and dark areas or to dis-cern objects in the visual ﬁeld (Gibson, 1966), as among the hard-wired abilities that support children’s later literacy de- velopment

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The ability to see light and dark or shapes comeswith the human system and is, clearly, not reading in itself

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Similarly, the human capacity to ﬁnd commonalities acrossexperiences, to form categories out of what is perceived, and to make cause and effect judgments supports and interacts with learning at all levels of interactive complexiﬁcation

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The ﬁrst level of the “what” dimension comprises ac- quired habits and conditionings representing simpler learned responses to the world that are often more concrete, are lesssocialized, and may require conscious awareness for a shorter period than other levels

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Returning to our literacy example, within a matter of months, most infants gain the ability to hear and pronounce a range of phonemes representative of the lan- guage around them, even as they learn to hold a book, graspthe corner of a page, and turn to the next

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: These acquired habits and conditionings will continue to support reading even as it progresses across levels

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: At the next level of the what model are the spontaneous concepts that humans acquire from the extraordinary num- ber of different learning opportunities they encounter, infor-mally or incidentally, over the course of a lifetime—from dressing one’s self to engaging in appropriate conversation, from cooking a meal to learning how to parent

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Such sponta-neous concepts, with their associated actions and emotions, can acquire the status of scientiﬁc concepts and practices, the next level, as when one realizes a love for and interestin cooking and takes up the preparation of becoming a chefor a food science expert

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The role of spontaneous concepts and actions is very evident in early literacy development, as when children begin to acquire print concepts and read- ing conventions through interactions with those that populate their environment or as a consequence of focused effort

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: When it comes to the third level of the what dimension, our choice of the term scientiﬁc concept follows usage in- troduced by Vygotsky (1934/1986) not to represent conceptsabout science as a discipline (or not only about science) but to refer to “languaged” ideas that have become abstracted or generalized from human interactions and aligned with formaldisciplines or communities of practice

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Thus, scientiﬁc con- cepts are often associated with intentional learning or formal knowledge (Gardner, 1991), in contrast to spontaneous con-cepts that are, in effect, less formalized understandings often acquired from everyday experiences (Vygotsky, 1934/1986) and often associated with unintended or incidental learning(Reber, 1989; Shiffrin & Schneider, 1984)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Thus, as one ex- amines the interactive complexiﬁcation of the “what” dimen- sion, there is an increased need for the support and guidance of others to assist in one’s learning (Anderson et al., 2001; Cobb, Wood, &Y ackel, 1991)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We represent this aspect bythe enculturation strand of the helix in Figure 1

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In addition, as the learning progresses across levels, there is the real possibility that a successful outcome will neces-sitate greater effort exerted across time and place (the effort strand)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Because reading development continues across the lifespan, there are many scientiﬁc concepts and practices thatcome as individuals engage in increasingly demanding, spe- cialized, and potentially more abstract print-related activities

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For instance, scientiﬁc concepts and practices come into playas individuals encounter technical or domain-speciﬁc texts or are introduced to new genres or new ways of analyzing a variety of traditional and nontraditional texts

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Overall, Figure 1 represents our attempt to portray how certain factors implicated in learning operate at varying de- grees and how their changing nature individually and in con-cert (what we call interactive complexiﬁcation) with other signiﬁcant factors constitute distinguishable levels of learn- ing’s objects or foci

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As we suggested, we contend that these levels and the interplay of factors they represent encom- pass the foci of a range of learning perspectives that mightotherwise appear at odds

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For instance, the whats that gar- ner much attention from behavior theorists would ﬁt well within the acquired habits and conditionings level of our de-piction, whereas the interests of sociocultural theorists may more often nest themselves at the level of scientiﬁc con- cepts and practices

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: What developmental theorists might em-phasize in their research, by comparison, is not the whats that fall at any one level of our representation, but rather the process by which individuals progress within and acrossthose levels

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Cognitive-evolutionary theorists, like develop- mental theorists, might be drawn to movement across levels, especially as it pertains to the ever-present inﬂuence of hu-mans’ inborn reﬂexes, abilities, and capacities on the nature

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: LEARNING TOPOGRAPHY 183 FIGURE 2 A model of the interactive nature of the what, where, and who dimensions of learning at time and across time (i.e., thewhen dimension)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Further, just as these individual strands contin- ually interact with each other to give the what dimension its character, so too does the what dimension interact with thewhere,who, and when dimensions to give learning its character, as we will see shortly (see Figure 2)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Dimension 2: The Where of Learning Learning does not happen in a vacuum

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The where of learn- ing refers to the ecological context in which learning occurs

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: By ecological context, we are referring to such primary as- pects as the physical environment and the social and culturalmilieu that are intertwined and interdependent in their inﬂu- ence on learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: An interesting characteristic of this ecology is that there is an intermingling of the more concrete withthe more abstract, and of the more physical with the more social, inﬂuencing the learning process at every turn

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As ina river system, there are physical elements and tangibles in the learning ecology that shape the ﬂow of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As well, there are social and cultural inﬂuences that emerge from the cultural practices and social dynamics in which the learning is taking place, especially as learning progresses toward thelevel of scientiﬁc concepts and practices

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Consider, for example, a 1-year-old who has discovered the wonders of banging a spoon on a highchair tray

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: At thispoint, banging requires a coordination of movement that may have begun accidentally but quickly developed into a rhyth- mic movement with its attendant cacophony of sounds

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Thephysical context impinging on learning may involve the pro- cessing of the distance between hand and tray and of how the spoon ﬁts in the child’s hand for maximum effect

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Atthis point, the social/cultural context may include how adults in the family interpret, react to, and label the child’s bang- ing and the particular kind of highchair and spoon that havecome to be used in that home

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As the child grows older, the context surrounding drumming may develop to include what it means to learn to play the drums musically, with all its related cultural practices

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Reading musical notation, knowing when to quiet a drumhead, and responding to a con-ductor’s subtle direction become contextual features to which the budding percussionist must appropriately respond, even as our learner reacts conceptually, motivationally, and emo-tionally to the degree to which this new skill is appreciated by the local culture

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Moreover, as learning proceeds, what the learner takes the context to be changes

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: This ever-changinginterpretation of what exactly is salient and relevant about the contextual ecology inﬂuences the process and products of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: One of many domains in which contextual inﬂuences have been studied is reading

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: It sometimes pertains to thetexts themselves, including their organization, structure, and features (Chambliss & Calfee, 1998; Meyer & Poon, 2001; Schallert, 1976)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Context can also refer to the physical placein which the reading occurs, such as in the home (Purcell- Gates, 2007), in the classroom (e.g., reading class or other content domains; Jetton & Alexander, 2004), or in out-of- school environments (e.g., libraries, museums, or everyday locales; Moje & O’Brien, 2001)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Or it can relate to the modeor medium of delivery, (e.g., online or hypermedia environ- ments; Leu et al., 2007)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Also, the where of reading can focus on the human resources that are present and that may serveto facilitate or inhibit the learning process or its outcomes (Allington, 2001; Almasi, 1995)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Finally, as with the other learning dimensions, the where of learning interacts with the what, who, and when (see Figure 2)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: To explore just one of these interactions, we want to highlight how a learner’s relation with context changes overtime

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: When one is learning something new, the particular physical environment and social/cultural setting are critical to how the learning proceeds

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In fact, these details of contextare so critical that often one’s initial steps in learning will

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: 184 ALEXANDER, SCHALLERT, REYNOLDS incorporate them as essential components of the learning, leading to learning that seems tied to the situation

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Theorists of a certain persuasion might claim that all learning is like this, situated in particular contexts of practice (Greeno & van de Sande, 2007)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: However, exactly because contexts arethemselves always changing, the learner must continue to ad- just, adapt, and broaden the application of what was learned and to respond appropriately to contextual cues in the hereand now that are close enough but slightly different from the context that was in place when learning “began.” Dimension 3: The Who of Learning With the who dimension, we are pointing to how learning is inﬂuenced by characteristics of the learner along biological, cognitive, experiential (including individual and cultural ex-perience), and affective (motivation/emotion) lines

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Further, we acknowledge that the particulars of all that a learner brings to a situation critically inﬂuence the process and product oflearning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Indeed, over time humans have evolved a number of innate learning capacities that have helped them become more efﬁcient and effective learners, thus enabling them tosurvive and prosper in their ecological niche

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For example, humans appear to have a capacity to distinguish between a temporal string of nonrelated stimuli and a similarly appear-ing string that displays a series of cause and effect relations (Bjorklund & Pellegrini, 2002; Kant, 1787/1963)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As we begin to explicate this dimension, we are aware that a frequent interpretation of learner characteristics aligns itself with measuring individual differences in achievementor performance on high-stakes exams

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Because our focus is on learning, we want to make explicit the distinction be- tween learning and achievement, concepts that we think havebeen conﬂated in the educational and psychological litera- tures (Alexander & Riconscente, 2005)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Because achieve- ment test scores measure performance and not learning perse, they include measures of factors not representative of learning either as process or product

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The kinds of learner characteristics that we consider im- portant are several

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We acknowledge that simply by virtue of evolved biology and how humans are wired, who the learner is plays acritical role in the learning process

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The embodied conscious- ness that represents the human learner cannot help but shape the learning process (Lakoff & Johnson, 1999)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For example, although it is highly unlikely to ﬁnd a personwith more than three times the normal working memory ca- pacity, there is always variation in working memory across humans, as well as in the capacities of the brain to processinformation efﬁciently

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: These differences can be detected in both the processes and products of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Readers’ ﬂuency is associ- ated in part with the graphophonemic abilities they bring tothe text, combined with their working memory capacity and their skill at producing the desired sounds and expressions apace

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Another source of inﬂuence on learning is represented by learners’ motives, intentions, and general psychologicaltraits

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: What are learners in a particular learning situation consciously or unconsciously seeking to accomplish

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Much attention has been paid to motivational and emotional differences among learners

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As this litera- ture reminds us, individuals not only manifest different goalsfor learning, but also ascribe different values to learning, have varied expectations for success (Linnenbrink & Pin- trich, 2003; Pintrich & Schrauben, 1992; Wigﬁeld & Eccles,2000), and experience different emotions during the pro- cess (Damasio, 2005; Pekrun, Goetz, Titz, & Perry, 2002)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Different psychological traits (e.g., persistence or extrover-sion) inﬂuence the learning of individuals even when they ﬁnd themselves more or less in the same physical context confronting the same cognitive task (Matthews, Zeidner, & Roberts, 2006)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The motives, intentions, emotional states, and interests of readers have garnered increasing attention in the last decade (Guthrie & Cox, 2001; Wigﬁeld & Guthrie, 1997)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: This grow- ing presence has illustrated that those who perform well ata given reading task or who manifest a positive learning trajectory in the domain have more than the neurophysio- logical basics

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: They also have a reported interest in read-ing generally or in the particular domain or topic of the text (Wade, 2001)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: They are more likely to report an orien- tation toward learning about the domain/topic than towardsimply doing adequately on the task (Hidi & Harackiewicz, 2000)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: They are also more apt to hold beliefs about them- selves as readers and about reading that will sustain themand promote their cognitive and affective engagement (Dai & Wanga, 2007)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Another example of learner characteristics that come into play in descriptions of learning is individuals’ previous learn- ing, the relevant knowledge they have acquired that they bring to bear in a particular learning situation (Anderson, Reynolds, Schallert, & Goetz, 1977)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We point to the extremely proliﬁc research on how prior knowledge inﬂuences learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Theparticular interface between what one knows and what one is learning intimately inﬂuences what is understood from the interaction and what one takes away from it

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In an interesting study that combined two of these ways of differentiating learners, Walker (1987) compared army en- listed personnel who were either high or low in aptitude tolearn (based on scores on a standardized ability measure) and high or low in knowledge of baseball (based on responses to factual questions about the game) on how well they remem-bered an oral play-by-play of a half inning of a ﬁctitious baseball game

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Results indicated that participants with high baseball knowledge did better than those with low baseballknowledge whether they came from the high- or low-ability

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In fact, within the high-knowledge groups, low- ability recruits recalled as much of the play-by-play account as high-ability learners, and the low-ability/high-knowledge group outperformed the high-ability/low-knowledge group

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Walker’s study is interesting in the context of our con- sideration of the importance of learner characteristics be- cause it juxtaposed two different ways of thinking of how learners can differ from one another

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: There are many otherstudies, some to which we have been intimately connected, that have demonstrated the clear impact that prior knowledge can have on learning something new (Alexander & Murphy,1998; Anderson et al., 1977; Goetz, Schallert, Reynolds, & Radin, 1983; Reynolds, Taylor, Steffensen, Shirey, & Ander- son, 1982)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In a review of the theoretical and empirical liter-ature on knowledge, Alexander, Schallert, and Hare (1991) offered a synthesis of the myriad of constructs associated with prior knowledge and showed how these interacted witheach other

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We close our discussion of this dimension with a point we have made in our descriptions of the what andwhere dimen- sions

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As we depict in Figure 2, the who dimension interacts with all other dimensions so that particular characteristicsof the learner are emphasized or deemphasized through in- teraction with what is being learned, in what context, and at different points in time

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: In effect, because people as learnersdiffer greatly, different facets of the who are instantiated or become more salient as the particulars of the what andwhen of learning unfold in time and space

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Dimension 4: The When of Learning Others have recognized, in their way, the what,who, and where dimensions of human learning (Jenkins, 1974)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: How- ever, the fourth dimension in our topography has received less consideration especially in interaction with the afore- mentioned learning dimensions.Y et just as learning does notoccur in a vacuum, there is always a temporal nature to learn- ing

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: As humans, our movements in the world are inevitably constrained both by time and space

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: With each impercepti-ble moment, the frame for learning has shifted, not merely because the place itself has changed (e.g., light refractions or creature movements), but because the learner himself orherself has changed, however inconspicuously, from Time 1 to Time 2

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: It is precisely because of the invasiveness of time throughout this topography that we conceive of it as a force that must be addressed

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: We ﬁnd that different renderings have in their purview, though rarely explicitly, many iterations and variations on the dimension of time, each representing different gradations inthe span of time considered or the distributions of events or the number of relevant experiences within a given interval of time

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Consider the time frames of evolutionary theories vis- `a-vis sociocultural, cognitive-contextual, developmental, and situated perspectives on learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For evolutionary theorists,the course of time that is of importance can be millennia or eras, as their primary concern is the mental adaptation and the consequent development of the human species as a result of mutation and natural selection

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Thus, one might study aspects of learning that are biologically primary (numeracy)or secondary (reading) or the role of evolved adaptation in human development (Ellis & Bjorklund, 2005; Geary, 2005; Pinker, 2002; Reynolds & Sinatra, 2005)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: From sociocultural perspectives, time is framed by the his- tory of a particular group, which could encompass months, years, or even centuries

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Thus, one might study the cookie-selling practices of Girl Scouts (Rogoff, 1990), the ways in which graduate students come to adopt the proper stances, idiom, and understandings of a discipline (Fox, 1994), or themeaning and import of literacy to individuals born at different points in the 20th century (Brandt, 2001)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The time perspec- tive of developmental psychologists, by comparison, is thehuman life span and the predictable neurobiological, motor, cognitive, socioemotional changes that come with matura- tion and experience

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The characteristics of young children as learners may be compared to those of older children, ado- lescents, or adults

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: By comparison, theoretical perspectivesconcerned with learning in situ appear more concentrated on the immediate temporal unfolding and on how words, ac- tions, or cultural artifacts are plied by individuals or groupsaround shared problems or tasks

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Time plays another role in certain orientations when learning is attributed to the fre- quency with which individuals encounter certain conditionsor are embedded in particular experiences

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Here, it is not time itself that matters but the ﬂow of experiences or the avail- ability of human and nonhuman resources that come with theﬂow of time

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The intersection of these time orientations with the what, who, and where dimensions of learning can be well illus- trated in the study of expertise development within complex domains (Alexander, 2003; Spiro et al., 1992)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For one, the ability of individuals to move out of a state of acclimation ornaivet ´e in any ﬁeld is predicated in part on their level of neu- rological and biological development; that is, the mind and body must be at some sufﬁcient level of maturation or expe- rience to beneﬁt from any potentially educative event

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Also, there are characteristics of the learner (the who) that becomerelevant in such development in that individuals may be more or less predisposed to the neurobiological, physical, cogni- tive, social, and motivational demands associated with anyparticular domain

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: That is why individuals can be positioned at signiﬁcantly different points in expertise development for each and every complex domain

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The same person may wellbe acclimated in physics, competent in statistics, but expert in linguistics

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Moreover, the human and nonhuman resources that in- dividuals will require will shift as they gain facility in the domain and as central principles of the domain become part of their knowledge core

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Of course, it is also assumed that thejourney toward expertise means that the objects of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: 186 ALEXANDER, SCHALLERT, REYNOLDS become increasingly more complex and that the processes and products of learning mirror that growing complexity

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Also, it is well documented that the attainment of expertise in any complex domain requires an extended period, many thousands of relevant exposures, and the tapping into theknowledge of others (either with or without their explicit support and guidance) who have likewise attained expertise in that domain (Ericsson & Smith, 1991)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: LEARNING DEFINED Now with the principles and dimensions of learning in place, we are ready to propose a deﬁnition of learning that operatesin concert with those principles and dimensions

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Learning is a multidimensional process that results in a rel- atively enduring change in a person or persons, and conse- quently how that person or persons will perceive the world and reciprocally respond to its affordances physically, psy-chologically, and socially

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The process of learning has as its foundation the systemic, dynamic, and interactive relation between the nature of the learner and the object of the learn-ing as ecologically situated in a given time and place as well as over time

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Within formal logic, it is considered essential not just to establish what a thing is, but also to note what it is not (i.e.,antinomy)

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Similarly, we think that our deﬁnition of learn- ing would be inadequate if we were unable to specify some aspects of what learning is not

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The principles that we pre- viously proffered serve us in this endeavor because certain characteristics of “not learning” are implicitly or explicitlystated within those principles

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: First, all innate capacities, those genetically and biologically programmed inborn as- pects of our humanness, inﬂuence learning but are in andof themselves outside the parameters of learning as we have conceptualized it

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Second, and related to the issue of innate- ness, the biological/neurological maturation of the humanorganism in and of itself does not constitute learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Third, the simple recall of that which was previously learned does not constitute learning per se; only when recall results insome new conﬁguration or change does it reach the level of learning

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Finally, although as sensory beings, humans are in continual physical contact with the world around them,only when those experiences leave some relatively enduring footprint do they fall within the realm of learning as we have deﬁned it

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: TOUCHSTONE CASES It is easy when dealing with fundamental constructs that describe human functioning to remain at an abstract level that does not allow for a valid test of notions against thecomplexities that a real learning situation would bring with it

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Learning is often so associated with formal instructional settings that it is easy to forget how ubiquitous it is

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Testing our developing notions about learning against different kinds of real-world situations challenges us to see whether ourviews are broad, comprehensive, and justiﬁable

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The three examples we chose involve different kinds of learners, each learning something at different levels and in different placesand times

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: For each case, we attempt to establish why it represents learning and how it sits at the nexus of the primary dimensions within our topographical framework

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Case 1: Biting Into a Cherry When Diane’s son, Robbie, was barely 2 years old, he had acquired some degree of experience with eating an array of“adult” foods

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: One might even say that he was skilled at bringing a spoon up to his mouth and swallowing yogurt or cereal he had scooped onto it from a bowl.Y et it oftenhappened that he would face some new substance and would have to learn about it, not only whether it was edible but also such characteristics as how it looked, how one should hold itto eat it, what to do with it in the mouth, and how it tasted

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: On a particular day, Robbie grabbed a cherry as his mother looked on, popped it into his mouth, and bit down

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Whatmade this otherwise insigniﬁcant step in Robbie’s knowledge acquisition of “cherry-as-foodstuff” memorable was the look of sharp surprise he displayed as his teeth met the pit of the cherry straight on

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: It was clear that he had not “predicted” a cherry pit and that he did not, in some essential way, knowhow to eat a cherry

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Where an adult carefully, albeit often automatically, negotiates the teeth around the center of the cherry and squeezes down making sure that the juice of thefruit stays inside the lips, Robbie had bit hard into the center of the cherry and had made bright red juice spurt out down the front of his T-shirt

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Even by his second cherry, he wasmore cautious in biting, more careful about the mess of the juice, and more eager to reproduce the taste of the fruit

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: He had learned how to eat cherries, or more accurately, how notto eat them, adjusting his teeth and lips so as to avoid painful effects

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: According to our learning framework, Robbie was devel- oping a simple set of acquired actions (habits) and responding to the effect of the punishing stimulation coming from the pain of biting into a hard substance and of spoiling his fa- vorite T-shirt with red cherry juice

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: What he had to learn in this situation—how to chew and how to position his mouthwith this new food—could not easily be acquired by imitation as most of what needed to be discovered was hidden from view.Y et his own physical sensations could “teach” him whatto do in this case

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Because Robbie was learning in a particular context, rep- resented by the physical environment (e.g., the objects on thepicnic table on the family patio, the presence of his mom and dad, the smells and tastes of the food, or the pain of having

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: LEARNING TOPOGRAPHY 187 bit into it wrong) and the social/cultural context (e.g., that his family loved cherries, that they saw them as a treat, or that they ate them directly out of a bowl) inﬂuenced whether he would want to have a cherry again, let alone know how to eat it

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: His learning was shaped by who he was as a learner ofcherry eating, his motives and likes, his ability to ﬁgure out how to position body parts so as to avoid pain and gain tasty sensations, his current level of maturation and knowledgedevelopment about this small domain, his favored status in his indulgent parents’ eyes, and a host of other characteris- tics that made him learn as he did on that particular occasion.Finally, because of his age and the number of times he had previously eaten a cherry, a trajectory to his learning could be envisioned even then

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Now at the age of 30, Robbie caneat cherries with the best of them

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: The acquired habit and conditioned response this child had learned would be immediately understood by a learningtheorist coming from a behaviorist perspective, although the details of context, personal motives, and interpretations of the experience would likely be seen as unnecessary and distract- ing

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Such a view might even downplay the importance of the maturational level of the learner even as it placed emphasison the feedback loop created by the pain sensations (and in less restrictive versions of the theory, the frustration of hav- ing spoiled a favorite shirt) on the acquisition of the properbehavioral production routines

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: By contrast, a sociocultural view might emphasize the meaning of a family picnic as a context to a child being introduced to a new food while over-looking, perhaps, the working out of the proper lip, teeth, and tongue movements required in eating a cherry properly

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: A cognitive-constructivist, on the other hand, might employthis case to illustrate the manner in which Robbie’s lack of experience and his still emerging schema for fruit-eating led to the undesired event and how this particular experiencewould likely add salient information to his mental model for cherry consumption

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Case 2: Crossing the Via dei Fori Imperiali in Rome In the second case, we describe what happened when Ralph, on a ﬁrst visit to Rome, had the occasion to cross one of themajor streets in Rome

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Taking off on foot from his hotel, he had already spent several hours navigating the ruins of the old Forum when he decided to visit the Piazza Campo de Fiori designed by Michelangelo

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Nothing particularly remarkable happened as he crossed several smaller streets on his waybut then he came to an extremely large street, Via dei Fori Imperiali, six lanes wide with vehicles crowding every lane and moving at a daunting rate of speed

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: Although critical elements of Ralph’s well-learned, Amer- ican street-crossing schema did not seem to apply, they did guide his attention in the search for a solution, a process thatin this rendering may seem much more protracted and analyt- ical than it actually was

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered
SENTENCE: First, he looked for a streetlight thatwould stop the trafﬁc, immediately ascertaining that there were none in sight

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered

TITLE: What is Learning Anyway- A Topological Perspetive Considered

SENTENCE: Nor do I feel it is imperative or even advisable to have but oneconceptual definition that can be applied to any complex educational construct

SENTENCE: However, aseducational research migrates farther and farther from the initial philosophical or psy-chological roots from which it arose, it is worthwhile, if not necessary, to take a critical look atthe constructs as they have more recently been conceptualized and operationalized and to compare them to their conceptual progenitors, as well as to presumably related terms

SENTENCE: It makes sense that those who wish to engagein basic research within the area of self-directed activity (or what some have historicallyreferred to as executive functioning or executive control; Brown 1975), or who desire to formulate interventions that promote self-regulated or self-directed learning and develop-ment, want to have as clear an understanding of their central constructs as possible

SENTENCE: Further, even though there have been recent reviews of the literature that inform the contributions to this special issue, those reviews have focused on one or another of these conceptual domains (e.g., self-regulated learning; Greene and Azevedo 2007)

SENTENCE: Indeed, the ensuing collection of works for this special issue has been chosen to bring several bodies of research into alignment so that key theoretical elements, methodologicalfeatures, and statistical dimensions can be compared and contrasted

SENTENCE: In some instances, those ensuing reviews involve literatures that have already been linked to metacognition, self- regulation, or self-regulated learning

TITLE: Why This and Why Now- Introduction to the Special Issue on Metacognition, Self-Regulation, and Self-Regulated Learning
SENTENCE: Finally, with the article by Maggioni and Parkinson (2008), the core ideas underlying this special issue are carried into a realm of empirical research that has not traditionally beenpositioned under the banner of self-directed activity, epistemic cognition

SENTENCE: What also dis- tinguishes this particular contribution is the purposeful focus on teachers and how meta- cognition or self-regulation manifests in educators ’beliefs about knowledge or the practice of communicating that knowledge to others, as well as in the calibration of their students ’ learning or their own performance

SENTENCE: To fully realize the goals for this issue, I sought the insights of three remarkable scholars who have long been invested in one or more of the cons tructs central to thisv olume

SENTENCE: Finally, Avi Kaplan (2008), whose body of work has touched on all three of our key constructs, boldly reframes the problem at hand, unwilling to accept the premise that we need to establish the boundaries between metacognition, se lf-regulation, and self-regulated learning

TITLE: Why This and Why Now- Introduction to the Special Issue on Metacognition, Self-Regulation, and Self-Regulated Learning

TITLE: Why This and Why Now- Introduction to the Special Issue on Metacognition, Self-Regulation, and Self-Regulated Learning

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: That is to say, they have been so named because I will begin each response with a statement of concurrence (“yes...”) before diverging from the authors ’explicit messages (“but...”)

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: with the contributors to this volume that the path toward tenure and subsequent promotions within research-intensive and research-extensive institutions islargely predicated on having a well-articulated and discernible research program

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: For instance, as Mayer (2008) outlined critical steps for conducting a successful research project and bringing it to closure, he emphasized the necessity for a guiding theoretical model and research questionsthat allow one to “contribute to a research base ”(p

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In keeping with Mayer ’s argument, many an article submitted to Contemporary Educational Psychology during my tenure as editor has been rejected in part due to this lack of an overarching theoretical frame that notonly ties the pieces of the manuscript together but also establishes its contributions to theexisting literature

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Yet…the qualities Mayer thoughtfully outlined for study design and manuscript development would be far easier to accomplish if young faculty were researching withina well-defined niche and had carved out a line of inquiry that carries their thinking (and thus the field) forward

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Said another way, it is not just the well-conceived and well-crafted manuscript that matters, but how one manuscript is part of a coherent program of researchand leads theoretically and methodologically to the next

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Of the many productive scholars Iknow, few match Richard Mayer in his ability to do just that —to see the next logical step in a program of inquiry

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: I also appreciated …McCormick and Barnes ’s(2008) articulation of steps that new faculty might take to establish the type of research program into which Mayer ’s systematically crafted manuscripts would fit nicely

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Among those recommendations, theseauthors talk about explicitly searching for collaborators once young faculty have arrived intheir new academic homes, learning about their colleagues ’research, and “attending research seminars, looking at websites and conducting Internet searches ”(p

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: 10) as potential sources of suitable lines of inquiry and viable collaborators

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: They also talked about using conferences as tools for networking and expanding one ’s base for collaboration

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Nonetheless …I would like to sound several cautionary notes about the insights that McCormick and Barnes forwarded

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Fundamentally, I am not convinced that young facultyshould seek positions under the assumption that they have the luxury of exploring a line ofinquiry suitable for them upon arrival

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Within research-intensive and research-extensiveinstitutions, young faculty have precious little time to formulate their research focus orconceptualize a program of inquiry

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In many institutions, preliminary decisions about ayoung faculty member ’s likelihood of success occur within the first 3 years of appointment

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Thus, when we search for new faculty we look for someone who already demonstrates thebeginnings of a productive research career, as evidenced by their record of publication, presentations, the timeliness of their research topic, and the like

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: At a minimum, the dissertation should signal the candidate ’s potential and should translate into one or more significant publications

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In fact, for our doctoral students there is the expectation that thedissertation will notbe their first research endeavor but rather an extension of the focus they have already begun to articulate.72 Educ Psychol Rev (2008) 20:71 –77

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Supporting Professional Development Without question …the reality of Halpern ’s(2008) explanation regarding the professional trajectory of women in academia is stark but undeniable

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: As she writes: “The reasons for the slow progress of women, especially when research demands are high, lie in the fact that faculty positions can be all-consuming in their time demands, which can make it very difficult to manage family-care responsibilities and a research-intensive academic career ” (p

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Later Halpern admonishes institutions of higher education to rethink the prevailingculture of practice

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: One way to help young faculty succeed is to change the workplace culture and rules so that they are supportive of valuable employees who also want to have children or to care for others ….There is good evidence that family-friendly workplaces are more productive and offer substantial returns to the employer

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: 62) There are personal reasons why I find Halpern ’s portrayal compelling

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: For one, while I was on faculty at Texas A&M University I chaired the Committee on the Status of Womenand remember the findings of an intensive study we undertook that revealed the lack ofprogress in moving women and underrepresented populations into the higher ranks ofacademia

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In fact, there had been almost no appreciable change in the 10 years of data wegathered across colleges and disciplines

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: That was almost 15 years ago, and the pattern indata shared by Halpern (2008) and Mason and Goulden (2002,2004) still reveal little progress

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Recently, I have become invested in understanding expertise development broadly and more specifically forthose from underrepresented populations

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: This research experience led me to consider the power of fragile competence orfragile expertise in undermining the progress of women, especially in scientific and mathematical fields

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In concert with Halpern ’s recommendations, there is reason to assume that blatant discrimination of the type discussed in the “Glass Ceiling ”cannot be held primarily accountable for the academic stagnation we are witnessing

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Rather, it would seem that moresubtle barriers, what I perceive as “academic undertows, ”can pull promising scholars down and stymie their progress

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Certainly, family-care responsibilities would be one of thosemajor academic undertows with which women must deal

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: My reason for referring to this phenomenon as fragile expertise is to emphasize that young scholars ’professional development is still in a precarious state when they exit their graduate programs —even if well trained

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: What is required is continued support and guidance as these scholars cross the threshold from graduate student to faculty member

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Not only are new skills and knowledge required of young academics, but those competenciesalready formed in graduate school must also be further reinforced and solidified

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Let me offer one additional side comment with regard to this call for continued nurturance of our young faculty

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In my work as a faculty mentor at the university level, Ihave found that the demands on women can be even greater in certain academic domainsthan others, not only due to the culture of the department, college, or university, but alsodue to the nature of the field itself

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: As a single parent and young faculty member, I facedlate nights and long hours trying to be productive while giving my child the time and carehe deserved

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Still, I had the benefit of working within a department and college that wasmore female-oriented and more sensit ive to concerns of psychology and human development

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: I could also work from home when the need arose.Educ Psychol Rev (2008) 20:71 –77 73

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Today, I work with women in fields where they are clearly minorities at all ranks and where it is impossible for them to take their work home

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Consider the relatively smallnumber of female faculty in Chemical Engineering, for instance

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In order to conduct theirresearch, these women must spend many hours in their labs without the ability to take thework home or bring their children into that work environment

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: I do not mean to suggest that the life of women and underrepresented populations is easy in educational psychology, just that it could be even harder

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Seek Balance It seems commonsensical …to say that balanced faculty will be more productive than those whose academic lives are out of kilter

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Indeed, several of the contributors to this specialissue admonish young faculty to find the balance not only between the facets of theprofessoriate but also between their lives in and outside the academy

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Throughout theirarticle, for instance, McCormick and Barnes (2008) outline strategies they perceive as useful “for balancing the multiple, and sometimes competing, demands and expectations ” (p

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Those strategies extend beyond a consideration of writing and research, whichrepresents the bulk of this dedicated volume, and address the dimensions of teaching andservice that often get less attention in young faculty ’s preparation

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: I applaud McCormick and Barnes ’s foray into those less trodden, but still critical, dimensions of the professoriate

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: While McCormick and Barnes focus their lens on life within the academy, Halpern (2008) turns her attention to the precarious balance between one ’s professional calling and one ’s personal existence

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: As she puts it: “Everyone has a life outside of work, and although we often talk about work and family (or, as some prefer, work and life) as separate constructs, realpeople live one integrated life, not two ”(p

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: For that reason, Halpern considers factors that could well disrupt this integrated life and sug gests proactive steps that could moderate their influences on young faculty, especially thosew ith primary family-care responsibilities

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: But…how can I quibble with these calls for balance or for the strategies that may permit one to negotiate the competing demands of the professoriate or life within and outside theacademy

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: I certainly believe that we function best and can sustain our professional liveswhen we give all facets of our professional and personal lives the attention they merit

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Yet, we cannot presume to dictate or standardize balance for any one individual according to some abstract criteria

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Balance has a variable character not only across individuals but alsowithin individuals across their professional careers

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: That is why women of child-bearingyears may face unique challenges (Halpern 2008) or why faculty from underrepresented populations may require special mentoring arrangements (McCormick and Barnes 2008)

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Still there are other factors that can shift the balance for individual faculty even at similar points in their careers

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: For instance, certain faculty find the demands of designing andreporting studies more onerous than others, while particular faculty see teaching as a moreeffortful, time-consuming, or unrewarding part of their job

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Still others find the political andsocial demands of the professoriate counter to their personalities or more exhausting thando their colleagues

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Certainly, if someone were to examine my life they would question its balance; but what represents balance to me, especially at this stage in my professional and personal lives, bears only slight resemblance to my life in the first years of my career

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Iwould not expect anyone to use me or my work style as a model of balance but I wouldargue that this level of effort both within the professoriate and across my personal life havesuited me well —a balanced imbalance, if you will.74 Educ Psychol Rev (2008) 20:71 –77

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Nihalani and Mayrath ’s(2008) argument that we engage in scholarly writing for multiple reasons

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In their overview of the observations and recommendations ofeditors for leading educational psychology journals, these contributors begin by offering four important functions that scholarly publications serve for academics

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Those four functions are as follows: First, publications serve to help a new Ph.D

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: get a job at an institution right away upon graduating ….Second, salary, promotions, and tenure weigh scholarly productivity more than any other factor —namely teaching and service ….Third, the ability to change jobs is almost totally dependent on the professor ’s publication record ….The fourth function of publications is that recognition and prestige are a direct function of a professor ’s scholarly publications

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: 30) Nihalani and Mayrath ’s litany of reasons for publishing are certainly pragmatic ones, and I have no doubt that most professors would agree on their analysis

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Yet…I must say that the primary reason why I conduct research and seek to publish that work does not appear at all among Nihalani and Mayrath ’s listings

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: In fact, I can say quite honestly that the driving force in my scholarly writings has never been to get a job, gaintenure, move institutions, or achieve recognition

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: But I have always perceived them as positive residual effects forbeing passionately committed to improving the educational experience of learners and tothe ideas and interventions that I believe can bring about such improvement

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Call me altruistic, but those are the compelling forces that led me out of the classroom and into the university in the first place

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Sharing these ideas and interventions with others whom I believe are equally committed to the academic development of all learners is why I publish

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: It could be that Nihalani and Mayrath took altruistic reasons for publishing asgivens and, thus, concentrated on the more pragmatic

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: Nonetheless, I feel it is important toexplicit such intrinsic reasons in our advice to young faculty

TITLE: Yes…But- Footnotes To Sage Advice
SENTENCE: That is because I believe thatif the ideas about which young faculty write have more power in and of themselves than theexternal rewards they may engender, then it will be easier to devote the incredible time andenergy required to bring those written ideas to fruition
